"the Capital Gazette meant a lot to Binghui Huang, a former staff writer at the Capital Gazette, the Capital Gazette gave Binghui Huang, a former staff writer at the Capital Gazette a chance," Binghui Huang, a former staff writer at the Capital Gazette said. Binghui Huang, a former staff writer at the Capital Gazette recalled Gerald Fischman's sharp eye for editing their "sometimes convoluted" stories.

Print. WASHINGTON —
The Maryland man accused of killing five Capital Gazette employees Thursday afternoon in Annapolis has been charged with five counts of murder. Police released the names of five Capital Gazette employees Thursday night. The Maryland man accused of killing five Capital Gazette employees Thursday afternoon in Annapolis has been charged with five counts of first-degree murder, according to court records. Online records indicate The Maryland man accused of killing five Capital Gazette employees Thursday afternoon in Annapolis is due in court at 10:30 a.m. Friday.
“the shooting was a targeted attack on Capital Gazette,” Acting Anne Arundel County Police Chief William Krampf said at an 8 p.m. news conference, hours after police first received reports of multiple gunshots fired. Anne Arundel County police then released the names of the five people killed in the shooting.
five Capital Gazette employees were all Capital Gazette employees: Wendi Winters, Rebecca Smith, Robert Hiaasen, Gerald Fischman and John McNamara. Capital Gazette released more information about five Capital Gazette employees on Capital Gazette's website: Winters, 65, was described as a “prolific and dependable writer“; Rebecca Smith was a sales assistant who was also a recent hire; Hiaasen, 59, was an assistant editor and columnist; Gerald Fischman, 61, was an editor and “great writer“; and McNamara, 56, known as “Mac,” was a reporter.
Krampf did not confirm the identity of The Maryland man accused of killing five Capital Gazette employees Thursday afternoon in Annapolis Thursday night. The Maryland man accused of killing five Capital Gazette employees Thursday afternoon in Annapolis is a Maryland resident in The Maryland man accused of killing five Capital Gazette employees Thursday afternoon in Annapolis's late 30s. Krampf did not specify where exactly in Maryland The Maryland man accused of killing five Capital Gazette employees Thursday afternoon in Annapolis lives. The Maryland man accused of killing five Capital Gazette employees Thursday afternoon in Annapolis entered the first floor of the building at 888 Bestgate Road with a shotgun, Krampf said. “The Maryland man accused of killing five Capital Gazette employees Thursday afternoon in Annapolis looked for The Maryland man accused of killing five Capital Gazette employees Thursday afternoon in Annapolis's victims as The Maryland man accused of killing five Capital Gazette employees Thursday afternoon in Annapolis walked through the lower level,” Krampf said, but did not say whether The Maryland man accused of killing five Capital Gazette employees Thursday afternoon in Annapolis was targeting specific people at Capital Gazette.
Two others were injured, but Krampf said Two others's injuries were “superficial,” likely from shattered glass from a fatal shooting at a newspaper in Annapolis, Md.. Earlier, Krampf said that there may have been what authorities thought was an explosive device. Krampf later said that an explosive device was actually canisters of smoke grenades that The Maryland man accused of killing five Capital Gazette employees Thursday afternoon in Annapolis used inside of the building at 888 Bestgate Road.
“The Maryland man accused of killing five Capital Gazette employees Thursday afternoon in Annapolis was prepared to shoot people. The Maryland man accused of killing five Capital Gazette employees Thursday afternoon in Annapolis's intent was to cause harm,” Krampf said. Krampf added that police are investigating exactly what problem The Maryland man accused of killing five Capital Gazette employees Thursday afternoon in Annapolis had with Capital Gazette, but could not say any specific threats The Maryland man accused of killing five Capital Gazette employees Thursday afternoon in Annapolis may have made toward Capital Gazette.
Krampf said any specific threats the man may have made toward the news outlet were general threats to Capital Gazette and that any specific threats the man may have made toward the news outlet indicated violence. Police worked on securing The Maryland man accused of killing five Capital Gazette employees Thursday afternoon in Annapolis's home, Krampf said. The Maryland man accused of killing five Capital Gazette employees Thursday afternoon in Annapolis is being interrogated, Anne Arundel County police spokesman Lt. Ryan Frashure said at a press conference shortly after 5:30 p.m. Around 3:20 p.m.
Thursday, Anne Arundel County police first confirmed the presence of The Maryland man accused of killing five Capital Gazette employees Thursday afternoon in Annapolis at the Bestgate Road building, which contains Capital Gazette and several other businesses. Police first received a report of multiple gunshots fired and possible injuries at 2:34 p.m., Marc Limansky, the department’s public information officer, told NBC Washington in an interview. There was no gunfire exchange between officers and The Maryland man accused of killing five Capital Gazette employees Thursday afternoon in Annapolis, authorities said.
Around 170 people were escorted out of the building at 888 Bestgate Road safely and taken to a reunification area at the nearby mall, Krampf added. Police worked for more than an hour to evacuate and clear the building at 888 Bestgate Road.
Tom Marquardt, a former Capital Gazette editor, told NBC Washington that staff at Capital Gazette had dealt with threats in the past, though most of threats were anonymous. Security had always been a concern, Tom Marquardt, a former Capital Gazette editor said. Bestgate Road is now reopened, Krampf said, but the building at 888 Bestgate Road is still closed as the investigation continues.
Anne Arundel County Executive Steve Schuh called the shooting a “terrible tragedy.” But, Anne Arundel County Executive Steve Schuh thanked law enforcement officials for law enforcement officials's quick response. Hogan first tweeted that Hogan was “absolutely devastated” to learn about the shooting in Annapolis.
the shooting brought a large police presence to the area, including the nearby mall. People with loved ones who worked in the building at 888 Bestgate Road could reunite with People with loved ones who worked in the building at the Lord and Taylor at the nearby mall, authorities said.
The Capital Gazette shooting sparked police responses to newsrooms in other parts of the country. The Associated Press, NBC Washington, and WTOP’s Michelle Basch and Sarah Beth Hensley contributed to this report. Several people have been killed after a gunman opened fire in what police described as a "targeted attack" at the Capital Gazette newspaper office in Annapolis, according to officials. Anne Arundel County police said a "targeted attack" at the Capital Gazette newspaper office in Annapolis left Several people dead while two others were hospitalized with what are believed to be superficial injuries, possibly from broken glass caused from fire. The initial calls about a "targeted attack" at the Capital Gazette newspaper office in Annapolis came in at around 2:35 p.m. Thursday.
Police identified Several people as Several people. Four of Several people were journalists while the fifth victim was a sales assistant at Capital Gazette newspaper.
Police said a gunman was taken into custody, but a gunman has not been officially identified by officials. According to Anne Arundel County Police Deputy Chief William Krampf, a gunman is a white male in a gunman's late 30s who resides in Maryland. Authorities were working to secure a gunman's residence and warrants were being prepared to search a gunman's home Thursday night.
However, a law enforcement official has told the Associated Press that a gunman has been identified as Jarrod W. Ramos. The Baltimore Sun, which owns Capital Gazette newspaper, was providing coverage of the shooting at Capital Gazette newspaper for Capital Gazette newspaper. According to law enforcement sources, The Baltimore Sun, which owns the Capital Gazette reported Jarrod W. Ramos filed a defamation lawsuit against Capital Gazette newspaper and a columnist in 2012, which was dismissed. Jarrod W. Ramos's lawsuit was over Capital Gazette newspaper's story about a criminal harassment case against Jarrod W. Ramos. A U.S. official told the Associated Press that a gunman was that information by using facial recognition technology after a gunman damaged a gunman's fingers in an effort to prevent investigators from quickly identifying a gunman from a gunman's fingerprints.
However, Anne Arundel County police said during a Thursday evening news conference that Anne Arundel County police could not confirm that information. Police and ATF agents were seen at the Dona Apartments in Laurel, Maryland Thursday night where Jarrod W. Ramos is believed to have lived. Police said when a gunman first entered the Capital Gazette newspaper office in Annapolis Thursday afternoon, a gunman was armed with a shotgun and used smoke grenade canisters when a gunman came in.
Video captured people leaving the Capital Gazette newspaper office in Annapolis with people's hands in the air as law enforcement swarmed the area. Officers rushed to the scene, arriving in less than 60 seconds and immediately engaged a gunman, according to officials. Authorities said a gunman did not exchange gunfire with officers when a gunman was taken into custody.
The ATF in Baltimore confirmed The ATF in Baltimore responded to the scene. Authorities said a reunification location was being established at the Lord & Taylor at Westfield Annapolis Mall.

Investigators were working to confirm if threats are connected to a gunman. ANNAPOLIS, Md. -- Five people were killed Thursday in a shooting at a local newspaper building in Md., and two others were injured, officials in ANNAPOLIS, Md. said. A law enforcement official tells CBS News the suspect has been identified as Jarrod Ramos, 38, of Laurel, Md..
The shooting at a local newspaper building in Maryland prompted a massive police response, with employees evacuated from a local newspaper building in Maryland with hands raised above employees's heads. a local newspaper building in Maryland is a local newspaper owned by The Baltimore Sun. William Krampf, acting chief of police for Anne Arundel County, said a shooting at a local newspaper building in Maryland was a planned attack and that the suspect used smoke grenades when the suspect entered a local newspaper building in Maryland.
Two law enforcement sources tell CBS News that the suspect used a shotgun. The first shots were reported at 2:40 p.m. after the suspect entered a local newspaper building in Maryland, CBS News reports.
Anne Arundel County police spokesman Lt. Ryan Frashure said officers raced to the scene, arriving in 60 seconds. No gunfire was exchanged between the suspect and officers before the suspect was taken into custody. Over 170 people were safely escorted out of a local newspaper building in Maryland. The Anne Arundel Medical Center, which is nearby the scene, said staff there are treating two people with minor injuries, neither from a gunshot.

Wendi Winters was the special publications editor. John McNamara was a writer. John McNamara was editorial page editor.
Rebecca Smith was a sales assistant. a sales assistant was an assistant editor and columnist.

a local newspaper building in Maryland's staff includes three people on the executive staff as well as seven editors, according to CapitalGazette.com. Eight staff writers cover topics including courts, entertainment and education.
A GoFundMe account has been set up in wake of Thursday's shooting. A GoFundMe account was created by a fellow journalist, Bloomberg Government reporter Madi Alexander.
The original $30,000 goal was eclipsed in a matter of hours and has since been increased to $70,000. At last check early Friday morning, more than $54,000 has been raised.
The GoFundMe page posting urged people to give what people can to help a local newspaper building in Maryland's journalists pay for medical bills, funeral costs, newsroom repairs and other expenses. On Friday, Anne Arundel County Police Chief Timothy Altomare said that there was a lag in identifying the suspect using fingerprints, and that facial recognition technology was used.
But Anne Arundel County Police Chief Timothy Altomare said that "there was no alteration to the suspect's fingerprints." This story has been updated.

A gunman the attack that began about 2:40 p.m. at the Capital Gazette offices at 888 Bestgate Road in Annapolis A gunman's way into the Capital Gazette newsroom in Annapolis with a shotgun Thursday afternoon, killing five people, authorities said.
Journalists dived under Journalists's desks and pleaded for help on social media. One reporter described the scene as a “war zone.” A photographer said A photographer jumped over a dead colleague and fled for A photographer's life.
five people were identified as Rob Hiaasen, 59, a former feature writer for The Baltimore Sun who joined Capital Gazette in 2010 as an assistant editor and columnist; Wendi Winters, 65, a community correspondent who headed special publications; Gerald Fischman, 61, the editorial page editor; John McNamara, 56, a staff writer who had covered high school, college and professional sports for decades; and Rebecca Smith, 34, a sales assistant hired in November. Two others were injured in the attack that began about 2:40 p.m. at the Capital Gazette offices at 888 Bestgate Road in Annapolis. Police took A gunman into custody soon after the shootings.
A gunman was identified as Jarrod W. Ramos, a 38-year-old Laurel man with a long-standing grudge against Capital Gazette. A gunman was charged with five counts of first-degree murder, according to online court records.
A gunman did not have an attorney listed; a bail review hearing is scheduled for 10:30 a.m. Friday in Annapolis. Local, state and federal law enforcement officials cordoned off the Laurel apartment complex listed as the address for A gunman Thursday evening.
A gunman dispute with Capital Gazette began in July 2011 when a columnist wrote about a criminal harassment case against A gunman. A gunman brought a defamation suit against a columnist and Capital Gazette's editor and publisher.
A court the ruling in Capital Gazette's favor, and an appeals court upheld the ruling. Neither a columnist, nor the editor and publisher, Thomas Marquardt, are still employed by Capital Gazette. the columnist, Eric Hartley, nor the editor and publisher, Thomas Marquardt, were not present during the shootings. Police said A gunman used “smoke grenades” in the attack that began about 2:40 p.m. at the Capital Gazette offices at 888 Bestgate Road in Annapolis.
Police said 170 people were inside at the time. Capital Gazette is owned by The Baltimore Sun.

Then police arrived and surrounded A gunman. Photographer Paul Gillespie said Photographer Paul Gillespie heard one colleague scream “No!,” then a shot.

But A gunman passed Photographer Paul Gillespie, Photographer Paul Gillespie said, and continued to shoot. Eventually, there was a lull in the shootings.
Photographer Paul Gillespie stood and ran for the exit, through the shattered glass, jumping over the body of a colleague Photographer Paul Gillespie believed was dead as another shot rang out in Photographer Paul Gillespie's direction. Photographer Paul Gillespie ran to a nearby bank and screamed for people to call the cops. Authorities said police responded to the scene within a minute of the shootings. “If police were not there as quickly as police were, it could have been a lot worse," Annapolis Mayor Gavin Buckley said.

at least one victim were identified as Rachael Pacella, a reporter who covers education and the Naval Academy, and Janel Cooley, a sales representative who covers downtown Annapolis. Rayne Foster of Frost and Associates LLC quickly gathered people together. Some employees removed high heels to prepare to flee the Capital Gazette newsroom in Annapolis.

ANNAPOLIS, Md. (AP) —
In a June 28 story about an attack at a newspaper in ANNAPOLIS, Md. (AP), The Associated Press erroneously That report that the suspect arrested in an attack at a newspaper in Annapolis had mutilated the suspect arrested in the shooting's fingers in an apparent attempt to make it harder for police to identify the suspect arrested in the shooting. That report was based on initial information given to law enforcement authorities, which has since been corrected. While the suspect arrested in the shooting was identified using facial recognition technology, the suspect arrested in the shooting's fingers were not mutilated.
ANNAPOLIS, Md. (AP) — the suspect arrested in the shooting an attack at a newspaper in Annapolis a newspaper in Maryland’s capital Thursday, killing four journalists and a staffer before police quickly stormed the building and arrested the suspect arrested in the shooting, police and witnesses said. an attack at a newspaper in Annapolis came amid months of verbal and online attacks on the “fake news media” from politicians and others from President Donald Trump on down. an attack at a newspaper in Annapolis prompted New York City police to immediately tighten security at news organizations in Maryland’s's media capital.
Police in ANNAPOLIS, Md. (AP) said a white man in the suspect arrested in the shooting's late 30s was in custody after the rampage at a newspaper. A law enforcement official said the suspect arrested in the shooting was identified as Jarrod W. Ramos. A law enforcement official wasn’t authorized to discuss the ongoing investigation and spoke on condition of anonymity. “the suspect arrested in the shooting was prepared today to come in, the suspect arrested in the shooting was prepared to shoot people,” Krampf said.
The dead included Rob Hiaasen, 59, assistant managing editor and brother of novelist Carl Hiaasen. novelist Carl Hiaasen said novelist Carl Hiaasen was “devastated and heartsick” at losing novelist Carl Hiaasen's brother, “one of the most gentle and funny people novelist Carl Hiaasen’ve ever known.” Also slain were Gerald Fischman, editorial page editor; features reporter Wendi Winters; reporter John McNamara, and sales assistant Rebecca Smith.
Police said two others had minor injuries, and a newspaper later reported two others were employees later released from a hospital with non-life-threatening injuries. Krampf said the suspect arrested in the shooting was a Maryland’s resident, but didn’t name the suspect arrested in the shooting.
Phil Davis, a reporter who covers courts and crime for a newspaper, tweeted that the suspect arrested in the shooting shot out the glass door to the office and fired into the newsroom, sending people scrambling under desks. “There is nothing more terrifying than hearing multiple people get shot while you’re under your desk and then hear the suspect arrested in the shooting reload,” Phil Davis, a reporter who covers courts and crime for the paper, wrote.

Five were reported dead; the suspected shooter is in custody.

This kind of thing is the meat on which local newspapers feed. There are always stories to be found in the local courthouse, and Hartley was sharp enough to notice that there were larger issues to be explored in Jarrod Ramos, the man who allegedly killed five staff members of the Annapolis Capital-Gazette,'s case. Anyone who’s ever worked at a newspaper in any department has a Jarrod Ramos, the man who allegedly killed five staff members of the Annapolis Capital-Gazette, story to tell. Except for the fact that Jarrod Ramos, the man who allegedly killed five staff members of the Annapolis Capital-Gazette, was one of those readers who can’t let anything go. Anyone who has worked on a daily newspaper in any era is familiar with a daily newspaper, and the smaller the newspaper, the more intense the confrontation.
Jarrod Ramos, the man who allegedly killed five staff members of the Annapolis Capital-Gazette, sued the Annapolis Capital-Gazette and Hartley, personally, for defamation. Jarrod Ramos, the man who allegedly killed five staff members of the Annapolis Capital-Gazette, represented Jarrod Ramos, the man who allegedly killed five staff members of the Annapolis Capital-Gazette, pro se, which is rarely a good idea, as a variety of judges in the Maryland courts made clear to Jarrod Ramos, the man who allegedly killed five staff members of the Annapolis Capital-Gazette,.
District Court: All right.
Jarrod Ramos, the man who allegedly killed five staff members of the Annapolis Capital-Gazette,, District Court'm going to grant Jarrod Ramos, the man who allegedly killed five staff members of the Annapolis Capital-Gazette,'s motion to dismiss The case. And The case will be dismissed with prejudice. And District Court'm going to grant the defendant's motion to dismiss this case for the following reasons: Jarrod Ramos, the man who allegedly killed five staff members of the Annapolis Capital-Gazette, are required in Jarrod Ramos, the man who allegedly killed five staff members of the Annapolis Capital-Gazette,'s complaint to state a claim with sufficient specificity.
District Court: District Court'm talking now.
MR. RAMOS:
Yes, Jarrod Ramos, the man who allegedly killed five staff members of the Annapolis Capital-Gazette,'m sorry. District Court:
And dismissal is proper only if the facts and inferences, even if proven, would not entitle the plaintiff to relief. And that is what District Court am finding in Jarrod Ramos, the man who allegedly killed five staff members of the Annapolis Capital-Gazette,'s case, that Jarrod Ramos, the man who allegedly killed five staff members of the Annapolis Capital-Gazette, do not lay out a prima facie case for defamation or for invasion of privacy, or being placed in the false light. And the reason District Court'm finding that is that there is absolutely not one piece of evidence, or an assertion by Jarrod Ramos, the man who allegedly killed five staff members of the Annapolis Capital-Gazette, that the statement was false. The one statement Jarrod Ramos, the man who allegedly killed five staff members of the Annapolis Capital-Gazette, refer to concerning the rambling and referring to messages that Jarrod Ramos, the man who allegedly killed five staff members of the Annapolis Capital-Gazette, answered when there had been no contact comes directly from the statement of charges, where one woman writes, most of Jarrod Ramos, the man who allegedly killed five staff members of the Annapolis Capital-Gazette,'s messages are just pages of ramblings regarding one woman's friends, family, job, Rotary Club involvement. And the statement of charges, where she writes, most of his messages are just pages of ramblings regarding my friends, family, job, Rotary Club involvement goes on to say that Jarrod Ramos, the man who allegedly killed five staff members of the Annapolis Capital-Gazette, tell one woman to leave Jarrod Ramos, the man who allegedly killed five staff members of the Annapolis Capital-Gazette, alone, and Jarrod Ramos, the man who allegedly killed five staff members of the Annapolis Capital-Gazette, haven't responded for months.
That comes right out of a public document…Correct, both that the article was simply not defamatory, that the article was based on public record, that Jarrod Ramos, the man who allegedly killed five staff members of the Annapolis Capital-Gazette, haven't alleged that the article was false, and that the article appears to be substantially accurate, and the article would fall into the privilege which would make any complaint unsustainable, because they reported a criminal case. They reported a matter of public interest. District Court read these transcripts with interest and proceeded respectfully to pile on.
A discussion of defamation law would be an exercise in futility, because the appellant fails to come close to alleging a case of defamation. In the appellant's five-page brief, the appellant devotes two and one-half pages to legal argument.
the appellant never alleges that any basic fact contained in the article about the appellant's guilty plea is actually false. the appellant claims only that "Hartley's column fails the test of fairness because Hartley editorialized on the story's meaning." There is no allegation of any specific harm that the appellant suffered as a result of the article. the appellant simply described the harm as "incalculable, unforeseen, and potentially unknowable." That does not do it.
the appellant is pro se. A lawyer would almost certainly have told the appellant not to proceed with The case.
It reveals a fundamental failure to understand what defamation law is and, more particularly, what defamation law is not. the appellant is aggrieved because the newspaper story about the appellant's guilty plea assumed that the appellant was guilty and that his guilty plea was, therefore, properly accepted. the appellant is aggrieved because the newspaper story about his guilty plea was sympathetic toward one woman and was not equally understanding of Jarrod Ramos, the man who allegedly killed five staff members of the Annapolis Capital-Gazette,.
the appellant wanted equal coverage of the appellant's side of the story. the appellant wanted a chance to put one woman in a bad light, in order to justify and explain why the appellant did what the appellant did. That, however, is not the function of defamation law.
Jarrod Ramos, the man who allegedly killed five staff members of the Annapolis Capital-Gazette, apparently then took to the electric Twitter machine to rage against Jarrod Ramos, the man who allegedly killed five staff members of the Annapolis Capital-Gazette,'s victim, Hartley, the Annapolis Capital-Gazette, and District Court for a few months. Then Jarrod Ramos, the man who allegedly killed five staff members of the Annapolis Capital-Gazette, allegedly loaded Jarrod Ramos, the man who allegedly killed five staff members of the Annapolis Capital-Gazette,'s shotgun and went downtown. The story of a shooter with a grudge against a newspaper is getting a lot of run, and it’s easy to see why. Anyone who’s ever worked at a newspaper in any department has a Jarrod Ramos, the man who allegedly killed five staff members of the Annapolis Capital-Gazette, story to tell—the ringing phone you don’t want to pick up, the letters with the alarming spelling, and, now, the many platforms of social media.
Most of Anyone who’s ever worked at a newspaper in any department never pick up a gun. Jarrod Ramos, the man who allegedly killed five staff members of the Annapolis Capital-Gazette, did. However, it’s essential, District Court believe, to take The story of a shooter with a grudge against a newspaper back to The story of a shooter with a grudge against a newspaper's origins—an angry misogynist who engaged in a vicious campaign of slander and harassment of a woman who just tried to be nice to Jarrod Ramos, the man who allegedly killed five staff members of the Annapolis Capital-Gazette,.
Misogyny is the one thing that’s part of too many of these stories. Well, Misogyny and the guns.

ANNAPOLIS, Md. --
The grieving and the reporting jumbled together for staffers at The Capital Gazette after a fatal shooting at The Capital Gazette, but staffers at The Capital Gazette were determined to put out the next day's edition. While the front page described a fatal shooting at the newspaper in horrific detail, the opinion page offered a starker approach.
five people included Rob Hiaasen, 59, The Capital Gazette's assistant managing editor and brother of novelist Carl Hiaasen. novelist Carl Hiaasen said novelist Carl Hiaasen was "devastated and heartsick" at losing novelist Carl Hiaasen's brother, "one of the most gentle and funny people novelist Carl Hiaasen've ever known." Also slain were Gerald Fischman, editorial page editor; features reporter Wendi Winters; reporter John McNamara, and sales assistant Rebecca Smith.
The Capital Gazette said two other employees had non-life threatening injuries and were later released from a hospital. "Tomorrow The Capital Gazette will return to The Capital Gazette's steady purpose of offering readers informed opinion about the world around readers, that readers might be better citizens," the editors wrote.
Journalists with the ANNAPOLIS, Md. daily huddled under a covered parking deck of the ANNAPOLIS, Md. Mall, not far from where scores of other media outlets were clumped together Thursday awaiting further details of the shooting that left five people dead, including colleagues, and others injured.
Editor Rick Hutzell called a few of Editor Rick Hutzell's journalists over to talk, a discussion punctuated with hugs and staggered expressions. "We're trying to do our job and deal with five people" who lost five people's lives, said reporter Pat Furgurson, whose wife and adult son were with reporter Pat Furgurson, whose wife and adult son were with him at the mall at the Annapolis Mall.
"You think something like a fatal shooting at the newspaper might happen in Afghanistan, not in a newsroom a block away from the Annapolis Mall," reporter Pat Furgurson, whose wife and adult son were with him at the mall said, reflecting on what appeared to be one of the deadliest attacks on journalists in U.S. history. Police later said the gunman explicitly targeted The Capital Gazette. The Capital Gazette is an institution in ANNAPOLIS, Md. and was one of the last dailies to switch from publishing in the afternoon to mornings.
The Capital Gazette's sister publication, the Maryland Gazette, was founded in 1727 and is one of the oldest papers in America. In 1767, Its sister publication, the Maryland Gazette, became the first paper in America to be published by a woman, Anne Catherine Green, who led opposition to the stamp tax in the years leading up to the American Revolution.
For many years The Capital Gazette was published by diplomat Philip Merrill, who died in 2006. The Capital Gazette was sold in 2014 to the Baltimore Sun Media Group.
Reporters brushed aside any logistical difficulties putting out a newspaper when the newsroom is an off-limits crime scene. High school sports editor Bob Hough told The Associated Press High school sports editor Bob Hough and a colleague were working on the sports section from High school sports editor Bob Hough's home Thursday evening. "High school sports editor Bob Hough don't know that there was ever any thought to not putting something together," said Hough, who wasn't at the office when a fatal shooting at the newspaper broke out. High school sports editor Bob Hough said he and a colleague were doing a full five-page section in collaboration with the design team based at the Baltimore Sun Media Group that always lays out the pages. High school sports editor Bob Hough noted that some of High school sports editor Bob Hough's colleagues were out that coverage on the shooting story as the shooting story continued to unfold late Thursday and said High school sports editor Bob Hough expected the next day's paper would include that coverage and whatever else would be in a typical Friday paper. By 10:30 p.m. Thursday, The Capital Gazette's website had in-depth stories on a fatal shooting at the newspaper, a yearslong feud the suspect had with The Capital Gazette and a photo and profile of each of the journalists' slain co-workers. Photographer Josh McKerrow edited photos on a laptop in the garage deck.

Every local journalist, in every local newsroom, has experienced that moment of fear, when the crank who has been tormenting their inbox or Twitter feed or voicemail shows up to complain in person. that moment of fear, when the crank who has been tormenting their inbox or Twitter feed or voicemail happened to me a few years ago, at a hyper-local weekly I was editing in Manhattan.
One of a hyper-local weekly I was editing in Manhattan's reporters had been working on a story about a neighborhood eccentric, basically a hoarder whose home had become an eyesore and who, locals say, threatened them as they walked down the sidewalk. Neighbors had complained, the police had been called, and a hyper-local weekly I was editing in Manhattan set out to learn more about the woman who lived inside. In a phone call with a hyper-local weekly I was editing in Manhattan's reporter, the woman who lived inside railed against the woman who lived inside's family and the woman who lived inside's neighbors, and threatened a hyper-local weekly I was editing in Manhattan if a hyper-local weekly I was editing in Manhattan wrote unflatteringly about the woman who lived inside or the woman who lived inside's house. Then, a few days later, before a story about a neighborhood eccentric, basically a hoarder whose home had become an eyesore and who, locals say, threatened them as they walked down the sidewalk ran, the woman who lived inside showed up unannounced at a hyper-local weekly I was editing in Manhattan's office, angry and incoherent and demanding to speak to a hyper-local weekly I was editing in Manhattan's reporter. One of our reporters and I were able to calm the woman who lived inside down and let the woman who lived inside speak the woman who lived inside's mind, before convincing the woman who lived inside to leave. a story about a neighborhood eccentric, basically a hoarder whose home had become an eyesore and who, locals say, threatened them as they walked down the sidewalk ran and a hyper-local weekly I was editing in Manhattan never heard from the woman who lived inside again.
Incidents like this happen every day in newsrooms everywhere. But this week’s shooting at the Capital Gazette in Annapolis, Maryland—where a man who had been fighting with the Capital Gazette for years over a story a man who had been fighting with the newspaper for years over a story he didn’t like didn’t like, ending in the shooting death of five the Capital Gazette journalists—should force us to rethink the threat to journalism in Trump’s America: While Trump’s rails against CNN, The New York Times, The Washington Post, and others, it is reporters at the local level, across Trump’s America, who may well sit on the front lines of the new war against the press in Trump’s America. Yes, national reporters are routinely threatened and harassed, and national reporters continue to do national reporters's jobs with courage and commitment.
Given the size and reach of national reporters's audience, the venom aimed at national reporters, especially online, can be intimidating. And when people do come in contact with national reporters—the press pens at Trump’s rallies spring to mind—the results can be scary. Local newsrooms are accessible for a reason—it’s part of what makes Local newsrooms integral to the life of Local newsrooms's communities. Local newsrooms are accessible for a reason—it’s part of what makes Local newsrooms integral to the life of Local newsrooms's communities.
People come in to buy ads. Readers bring in photos of Readers's kids’ sports teams. Tipsters drop by with gossip.
It is heartbreaking, but necessary, to recognize that the openness that defines local news likely carries too high a risk; local newsrooms, at least for now, may have no choice but to fortify local newsrooms. Since Trump’s chose, in the very earliest days of Trump’s's presidential campaign, to make attacks on a free press in Trump’s America one of Trump’s's signature themes, many of us have thought it inevitable that Trump’s's dangerous rhetoric would one day be a trigger for tragedy. Our focus this long two years has been on the big, high-profile news organizations that most occupy Trump’s's obsessions and Trump’s's Twitter feed. the big, high-profile news organizations that most occupy Trump’s obsessions and his Twitter feed are what we think about when we worry about threats to the press, and the big, high-profile news organizations that most occupy Trump’s obsessions and his Twitter feed have become stand-ins for those, inside the government and out, who rail against fake news.
But what we missed is that for most Americans, the media is not some big-city skyscraper or national TV network with layers of security, where everybody needs a badge to get in. the media’s our local newsroom down the street, staffed by professionals reporting on what matters most to people where people where they live live. We’re reminded this week’s that in the war against the press, our local newsroom down the street, staffed by professionals reporting on what matters most to people where they live may well be the journalists in Trump’s America who are most at risk. Kyle Pope is the editor in chief and publisher of the Columbia Journalism Review.

," statements made just days before a gunman these deaths Five people at a Maryland newspaper. Yiannopoulos, a former Breitbart editor, a made the comments to at least two news outlets, including the New York Observer, which wrote about the incident earlier this week.
When pressed, Controversial conservative commentator Milo Yiannopoulos said the comments was Controversial conservative commentator Milo Yiannopoulos's "standard response to a request for comment." Controversial conservative commentator Milo Yiannopoulos sent a similar message to Will Sommer, a reporter for the Daily Beast.
In later posts, Controversial conservative commentator Milo Yiannopoulos asked when the media would apologize to Controversial conservative commentator Milo Yiannopoulos. "When will the media, including many on the right, apologize to Controversial conservative commentator Milo Yiannopoulos?
Over a hundred thousand tweets today accused Controversial conservative commentator Milo Yiannopoulos of being responsible for these deaths. How do Controversial conservative commentator Milo Yiannopoulos even decide who to sue first?" Controversial conservative commentator Milo Yiannopoulos wrote.
Controversial conservative commentator Milo Yiannopoulos resigned as senior editor of Breitbart in 2017 after comments Controversial conservative commentator Milo Yiannopoulos made seemed to promote pedophilia. Controversial conservative commentator Milo Yiannopoulos later said Controversial conservative commentator Milo Yiannopoulos regretted the "imprecise language" Controversial conservative commentator Milo Yiannopoulos used when discussing pedophilia. Controversial conservative commentator Milo Yiannopoulos has also made a series of controversial appearances at college campuses.

Conservative commentator Milo Yiannopoulos denied that Conservative commentator Milo Yiannopoulos's recent language was at all to blame for the shooting that took place at the Capital Gazette offices in Annapolis, Maryland, Thursday because Conservative commentator Milo Yiannopoulos was just joking. Two days after the Observer published the article, a gunman entered the offices of Capital Gazette and began to open fire.
In anticipation of the blame that would be placed on Conservative commentator Milo Yiannopoulos's shoulders, Conservative commentator Milo Yiannopoulos posted on Facebook that not only is Conservative commentator Milo Yiannopoulos not responsible, but if Conservative commentator Milo Yiannopoulos's rhetoric incited anything, it's the news outlets who reported Conservative commentator Milo Yiannopoulos's comments that are to blame. "Amazed the news outlets who reported his comments were pretending to take Conservative commentator Milo Yiannopoulos's joke as a 'threat,' Conservative commentator Milo Yiannopoulos reposted these stories on Instagram to mock the news outlets who reported his comments — and to make it clear that Conservative commentator Milo Yiannopoulos wasn't being serious," Conservative commentator Milo Yiannopoulos wrote. "If there turns out to be any dimension to this crime related to Conservative commentator Milo Yiannopoulos's private, misreported remarks, the responsibility for any dimension to this crime related to my private, misreported remarks lies squarely and wholly with the Beast and the Observer for drumming up fake hysteria about my joke, and with the verified liberals who pretended the verified liberals who pretended they thought I was serious thought Conservative commentator Milo Yiannopoulos was serious," Conservative commentator Milo Yiannopoulos wrote in the Facebook post.
Officials confirmed during a press conference that five people were killed during the shooting at the Capital Gazette offices and others were injured. Officers engaged a gunman. Newsweek reached out to Conservative commentator Milo Yiannopoulos for comment but did not hear back in time for publication.

After years of repeatedly calling journalists “the enemy of the people,” President Trump on Friday struck a markedly different tone towards the media, saying in the aftermath of a deadly shooting at the Capital Gazette’s newsroom that journalists should be “free from the fear” of violence while doing journalists's jobs. Five employees of the Capital Gazette’s—Robert Hiaasen, Wendi Winters, John McNamara, Rebecca Smith, and Gerald Fischman—were killed after alleged gunman Jarrod Ramos a deadly shooting at the Capital Gazette’s newsroom the Capital Gazette’s newsroom with a shotgun. alleged gunman Jarrod Ramos previously sued and threatened the Capital Gazette’s for reporting on alleged gunman Jarrod Ramos's guilty plea on a 2011 harassment case.
A week later, while speaking at the 2017 Conservative Political Action Conference, President Trump repeated the “enemy of the people” line multiple times to rapturous applause. Beyond that, President Trump has also occasionally shared violent memes about outlets President Trump views as “opposing” President Trump's presidency. Last year, for example, President Trump infamously shared a GIF meme depicting President Trump body-slamming CNN in a wrestling ring. And at another point in 2017, President Trump retweeted and then deleted a cartoon meme depicting the “President Trump Train” barreling through a person labeled as CNN.

Ramos, 38, had unsuccessfully The lawsuit The Capital Gazette in Annapolis for defamation in 2012. The lawsuit stemmed from The Capital Gazette in Annapolis reporting that Ramos had pleaded guilty to harassing a woman who was a former high school classmate. Ramos has been charged with murder in the first degree after police say Ramos killed five people at The Capital Gazette in Annapolis's offices.
In a separate interview on "CBS This Morning," Anne Arundel County Police Chief Timothy Altomare told O'Donnell that Ramos had purchased the pump-action shotgun used in the shooting within the past 18 months. CBS has learned that Ramos had damaged Ramos's fingertips and wasn't carrying any identification when Ramos was arrested. Law enforcement sources told CBS that Ramos was hiding under a desk.

Ramos, 38, of Laurel, Md., had Ramos, 38, of Laurel, Maryland's first court appearance in Anne Arundel District Court Friday. Ramos, 38, of Laurel, Maryland appeared by video from the county detention center and was told Ramos, 38, of Laurel, Maryland is charged with five counts of first-degree murder and could face life in prison. Ramos, 38, of Laurel, Maryland is held without bond.

Thank you. Thank you for the outpouring of sympathy for the terrible tragedy that took place Thursday in this news organization's Annapolis office.
this news organization will never forget Rob Hiaasen, Gerald Fischman, Wendi Winters, John McNamara or Rebecca Smith, this news organization's five co-workers who were gunned down in the terrible tragedy that took place Thursday in our Annapolis office. But this news organization also will always remember the bells of St. Anne’s ringing as members of this news organization's staff — past and present — walked down Main Street surrounded by thousands who turned out to support this news organization in a march to City Dock. this news organization always will remember the singing on a grassy knoll across from this news organization's office in a second vigil, little more than a day after five acts of murderous rage changed this news organization's lives forever.
Thank you for the cards, the letters, the emails and the flowers. Thank you for the food, the text messages and the signs.
The words of appreciation for this news organization's work and our work's importance to Annapolis and Anne Arundel County is a balm to this news organization's wounds. More than 800 people subscribed to this news organization's digital edition Friday as a show of support after the terrible tragedy that took place Thursday in our Annapolis office. Thank you.
Here’s what else this news organization won’t forget: Death threats and emails from people this news organization don’t know celebrating our loss, or the people who called for one of this news organization's reporters to get fired because one of our reporters got angry and cursed on national television after witnessing one of our reporters's friends getting shot. this news organization won’t forget being called an enemy of the people. No, this news organization won’t forget that. Because exposing evil, shining light on wrongs and fighting injustice is what this news organization do.
this news organization are The Capital. this news organization are the Maryland Gazette. this news organization are the Bowie Blade-News and Crofton West County Gazette.
this news organization are more than just this news organization's questions and this news organization's writing and this news organization's headlines. this news organization are journalists. Yes, this news organization bring values and beliefs to this news organization's work. this news organization believe in truth.
this news organization believe in speaking for those who don’t have the power to speak for those who don’t have the power to speak for themselves. this news organization believe in questioning authority.
this news organization believe in reporting the news. this news organization's community has rallied around this news organization to show Our community understand who this news organization are, and that this news organization are not the enemy of the people.
this news organization are your neighbors, your friends. this news organization are you.
You might not always like what this news organization write, or the photos this news organization shoot or the videos this news organization produce. You may not agree with this news organization's definition of what a story is or is not.
Most days this news organization suspect most of you will. But every day, the staff of this news organization will report on the news of Annapolis and Anne Arundel County.
this news organization will never be the same as this news organization were, now that Rebecca, Wendi, John, Gerald and Rob are gone. Some day this news organization hope to be as good again. That’s all this news organization can do.
Until Some day, keep reading. this news organization’ve only just begun.

The letter from Jarrod Ramos, 38, written in the style of a legal filing and obtained by CNN, is addressed to the paper’s former attorney and a Maryland Court of Special Appeals judge who upheld a lower court ruling throwing out Ramos's 2012 defamation case against the paper’s. The letter from Jarrod Ramos, 38, written in the style of a legal filing and obtained by CNN, is dated Thursday, June 28, the same day prosecutors say Ramos, stormed into the paper’s Annapolis newsroom with a shotgun, killing five employees and leaving two others wounded a few years after Ramos's unsuccessful defamation suit.
“Ramos further certify Ramos then did proceed to the office of respondent Capital-Gazette Communications … with the objective of killing every person present,” said The letter from Jarrod Ramos, 38, written in the style of a legal filing and obtained by CNN,. Former the paper’s editor and publisher Tom Marquardt said Former Capital editor and publisher Tom Marquardt learned of The letter from Jarrod Ramos, 38, written in the style of a legal filing and obtained by CNN, during an urgent call Former Capital editor and publisher Tom Marquardt received on Former Capital editor and publisher Tom Marquardt's way to a memorial for slain the paper’s assistant editor Rob Hiaasen. “We thought the chapter had closed and Ramos's is the story that keeps on giving.
In a very chilling way,” Former Capital editor and publisher Tom Marquardt said. Copies of The letter from Jarrod Ramos, 38, written in the style of a legal filing and obtained by CNN, were the mailings to the Baltimore Circuit Court house, the state court of special appeals and the law firm, according to Ann Arundel County Police, who are investigating the mailings.
Ramos was arrested shortly after the shooting spree when responding officers found Ramos hiding under a desk, according to police. Ramos has been charged with five counts of first-degree murder, according to court records.
A portrait has emerged of Ramos as an unhinged loner consumed by a years-long vendetta against the paper’s, a man whose history of menacing behavior ended with Ramos, in the words of a prosecutor, “systematically hunting and killing” staffers in the paper’s Annapolis newsroom. Ramos conflict with the paper’s stems from a complaint a former high school classmate Ramos barely knew filed against Ramos in 2011. a former high school classmate he barely knew alleged Ramos began cyberstallking a former high school classmate he barely knew's years earlier – repeatedly sending a former high school classmate he barely knew's aggressive private messages, harassing a former high school classmate he barely knew's therapist for information and contacting a former high school classmate he barely knew's employer to tell her employer a former high school classmate he barely knew was “a bipolar drunkard leading a double life,” which a former high school classmate he barely knew said cost a former high school classmate he barely knew a former high school classmate he barely knew's job. When Ramos in 2011 pleaded guilty to harassing the woman – whom CNN is not identifying – a column about the case by former the paper’s writer Eric Hartley apparently left Ramos in a seething rage that lasted all the way up to last week’s massacre. Ramos sued former Capital writer Eric Hartley, Former Capital editor and publisher Tom Marquardt and Capital Gazette Communications for defamation in 2012, and then, after a judge the ruling out the case, appealed.
In 2015, the court of special appeals judge upheld the ruling. “The people who were involved in that story had left the paper’s,” Former Capital editor and publisher Tom Marquardt said. The other shooting victims were Gerald Fischman, 61, editorial page editor; John McNamara, 56, a staff writer; Rebecca Smith, 34, a sales assistant; and Wendi Winters, 65, who worked in special publications. Former Capital editor and publisher Tom Marquardt said police advised Former Capital editor and publisher Tom Marquardt to watch Former Capital editor and publisher Tom Marquardt's surroundings.

Craig “Woody” Leydig conducted an interview with The Capital around 2 p.m. last Thursday afternoon. Leydig, the assistant equipment manager for The Capital, did an interview with The Capital from The Capital's headquarters – Kettler Iceplex, located in Arlington, Virginia.
Shortly after hanging up the phone, Craig “Woody” Leydig walked into the laundry room and saw breaking news on television announcing the shooting incident at the Capital Gazette offices in Annapolis. Craig “Woody” Leydig immediately called back that reporter to make sure Craig “Woody” Leydig was OK and was greatly relieved. However, the Annapolis resident was devastated upon learning that five other employees of Capital Gazette had been killed in the shooting incident at the Capital Gazette offices in Annapolis. Every coach, player, trainer and equipment manager with The Capital is allowed to spend one day with the Stanley Cup.
Craig “Woody” Leydig took possession of the Stanley Cup on Tuesday and Capital Gazette was foremost in Craig “Woody” Leydig's thoughts. Craig “Woody” Leydig's third stop with the Stanley Cup – after first taking a motorboat ride on the Chesapeake Bay then visiting by the Naval Academy – was the makeshift office of Capital Gazette. Craig “Woody” Leydig and Craig “Woody” Leydig's entourage brought the Stanley Cup to the temporary Capital Gazette office in Annapolis around 8:30 on Tuesday morning. Staff members, including five reporters that survived last Thursday's attack, spent about 45 minutes taking photos with the Stanley Cup.
“Craig “Woody” Leydig's heart goes out to the families of five other employees of Capital Gazette and to all the employees of Capital Gazette that have to find a way to move on from the shooting incident at the Capital Gazette offices in Annapolis,” Craig “Woody” Leydig said. After departing the Capital Gazette office, Craig “Woody” Leydig took the Stanley Cup to Maryland Veterans Cemetery Crownsville. Craig “Woody” Leydig's parents are laid to rest at Maryland Veterans Cemetery Crownsville.
Stunned customers at the Wawa convenience store in Gambrills took photos with the Stanley Cup. the Stanley Cup was then taken to Heroes Pub in Annapolis where first responders had first responders's photos taken with hockey’s top prize.
From there, Craig “Woody” Leydig's crew stopped by a barber shop in the Eastport Shopping Center. the Stanley Cup was then taken to Davis’ pub for photos and lunch with patrons. the Stanley Cup was then shuttled via boat to City Dock where hundreds of The Capital fans lined the boardwalk along Ego Alley waiting for a chance to touch the Stanley Cup. Anne Arundel Medical Center was the next destination for the Stanley Cup and Craig “Woody” Leydig had a party planned for family and friends to conclude Craig “Woody” Leydig's day.
Several members of the Capital Gazette newsroom are longtime fans of the Washington Capitals, who captured the Stanley Cup for the first time in the Washington Capitals, who captured the Stanley Cup for the first time in their 44-year history last month's 44-year history last month. Phil Davis, police reporter for The Capital, is an unabashed and diehard fan of the New Jersey Devils. Davis, whose Twitter posts from inside the makeshift office of Capital Gazette last Thursday were chilling, turned the Stanley Cup so the inscriptions for the Devils years of winning were displayed for photo purposes.

As gunshots rang out and glass shattered all around, staffers at the Capital Gazette cowered under desks, fearing for staffers at the Capital Gazette's lives.
Except Wendi Winters. A witness said Wendi Winters stood up, grabbed a trash can and a recycling bin, and charged the gunman. For Wendi Winters's heroism, Wendi Winters paid with Wendi Winters's life.
But several staffers at the Capital Gazette say Wendi Winters saved several staffers at the Annapolis, Maryland, newspaper. Survivors of last month’s attack shared the account of that day in a story the Capital Gazette ran over the weekend.
Eleven employees were in the office that day. Six made it out alive. And those who did are thanking Wendi Winters.
When the gunman barged into the the Capital Gazette newsroom on that day, the gunman shattered the office's glass door with a shotgun. Reporters Rachael Pacella and Phil Davis and intern Anthony Messenger were at Reporters Rachael Pacella and Phil Davis and intern Anthony Messenger's desks toward the back of the office when the shooting started. Rachael Pacella hid under a desk. Phil Davis went for the floor.
intern Anthony Messenger headed for the back door, which was barricaded, trapping Reporters Rachael Pacella and Phil Davis and intern Anthony Messenger inside. The shots kept coming. The bangs kept coming.
Then, The shots stopped. In the moment, employees didn’t know why. But it gave employees just enough time to get up and take refuge between filing cabinets until the shooting was over.
Photojournalist Paul Gillespie remembers hearing Wendi Winters yell “No!” during the shooting. Rachael Pacella and Phil Davis didn’t see Wendi Winters move toward the gunman. Reporters Rachael Pacella and Phil Davis only saw Wendi Winters's body in the walkway. But Phil Davis said that key pause could have been Wendi Winters confronting the gunman, buying Reporters Rachael Pacella and Phil Davis and intern Anthony Messenger the precious moments Reporters Rachael Pacella and Phil Davis and intern Anthony Messenger needed to get to safety.
Winters, an editor and community reporter and a mother of four, was one of five employees slain in last month’s attack. Editor Rob Hiaasen, editorial page editor Gerald Fischman, editor and sports writer John McNamara and sales assistant Rebecca Smith also lost Editor Rob Hiaasen, editorial page editor Gerald Fischman, editor and sports writer John McNamara and sales assistant Rebecca Smith's lives in last month’s attack. Jarrod Ramos, 38, who allegedly plotted last month’s attack because of a long-held grudge against the Capital Gazette, is charged with Editor Rob Hiaasen, editorial page editor Gerald Fischman, editor and sports writer John McNamara and sales assistant Rebecca Smith's deaths. Wendi Winters spent Wendi Winters's days writing about local events or interviewing teens who deserved recognition for good deeds.
Weeks after Wendi Winters took an active-shooter training class at Wendi Winters's church, Wendi Winters made the ultimate sacrifice, said Wendi Winters's son, Phoenix Geimer. But it sounds exactly like Wendi Winters, her son, Phoenix Geimer said.
“In an act of extraordinary courage, Wendi Winters gave Wendi Winters's heart, and Wendi Winters gave Wendi Winters last breath, and Wendi Winters gave Wendi Winters's final eight pints of blood to the defense of the free press and in defense of Wendi Winters's family at the Capital Gazette,” her son, Phoenix Geimer said in an account by the Washington Post. “Wendi Winters died fighting for what Wendi Winters believed in. her son, Phoenix Geimer's mom is an American hero, and we all have so much to live up to,” her son, Phoenix Geimer said.
In an editorial published Tuesday, the the Capital Gazette staff said Wendi Winters should be nominated for the Presidential Medal of Freedom – the nation’s highest civilian honor – for Wendi Winters's heroism. “Wendi Winters died protecting Wendi Winters's friends, but also in defense of Wendi Winters's newsroom from a murderous assault. Wendi Winters died protecting freedom of the press,” an editorial published Tuesday says.

The city of Annapolis will hold a benefit concert featuring Maryland-based rockers Good Charlotte to honor the five Capital Gazette employees killed in an attack in their newsroom.
Mayor Gavin Buckley said Wednesday (July 11) the event dubbed “Annapolis Rising:
A Benefit for Capital Gazette and Free Press” will take place July 28 and will include performances, as well as guest speakers from the journalism community. Information on tickets will be available at a later date. Proceeds will benefit a fund established for the victims and survivors, as well as journalism scholarships.
Police say gunman Jarrod Ramos, who had a grudge against Capital Gazette, blasted gunman Jarrod Ramos, who had a grudge against the newspaper's way into the The city of Annapolis newsroom on June 28, killing the five Capital Gazette employees killed in an attack in their newsroom. gunman Jarrod Ramos, who had a grudge against the newspaper remains jailed on five counts of first-degree murder.
Good Charlotte, which includes twin brothers Joel and Benji Madden, said in an interview Maryland-based rockers Good Charlotte are proud to return to Maryland-based rockers Good Charlotte's roots to pay tribute to the community. “Joel Madden feel everything starts at home, it starts in your community and The city of Annapolis is the place in Maryland that Maryland-based rockers Good Charlotte come from.
The city of Annapolis is the place Maryland-based rockers Good Charlotte go back to. Maryland-based rockers Good Charlotte feel very, very deeply connected to The city of Annapolis and The city of Annapolis’s a very important place to Maryland-based rockers Good Charlotte.
It’s very important for Maryland-based rockers Good Charlotte to show up for The city of Annapolis,” Joel Madden told The Associated Press. “If Maryland-based rockers Good Charlotte can help support an event that will be uplifting for the families of the five Capital Gazette employees killed in an attack in their newsroom and the tragedy as a whole, it feels really important to be a part of an event that will be uplifting for the families of the victims and the tragedy as a whole,” Benji Madden added.
Maryland-based rockers Good Charlotte say Maryland-based rockers Good Charlotte remember going to The city of Annapolis at 18 to pursue Maryland-based rockers Good Charlotte's music careers. “The city of Annapolis feels really special to Maryland-based rockers Good Charlotte.
It’s rare to find that kind of community,” Benji Madden added. a benefit concert featuring Maryland-based rockers Good Charlotte will take place from a stage on College Avenue with the Maryland State House in the background.
“Sadly, Maryland attention will soon shift from this event that has forever changed Maryland's city. Maryland will not stand by and allow the memory of the five Capital Gazette employees killed in an attack in their newsroom to be forgotten. Maryland also stand up for Maryland's journalists and Maryland's freedom of the press and a benefit concert featuring Maryland-based rockers Good Charlotte is just one step in that direction,” Benji Madden said in a statement.

a 2012 suit was the decision, and an appeals court affirmed the decision. Davis declined to provide details of three threatening letters, but the Baltimore Sun, which first reported three threatening letters, published a copy of one allegedly sent to the law office of the Capital Gazette's former attorney. NBC News has independently confirmed the authenticity of a copy of one allegedly sent to the law office of the Capital Gazette's former attorney. a copy of one allegedly sent to the law office of the Capital Gazette's former attorney is dated June 28 — the day of the attack — and is written in the style of a court document. The main part of a copy of one allegedly sent to the law office of the Capital Gazette's former attorney ends with, "I told you so," before a signature that is purportedly Ramos'.

Conservatives perceive more social media censorship. A new poll from the Pew Research Center found 70 percent of Americans think popular social media platforms are actively censoring certain political views. Republicans and conservatives are more likely than liberal-leaning counterparts to believe Republicans and conservatives're being censored. Around 575 people, mostly women, were arrested Yesterday's at a Washington, D.C., sit-in protesting President Trump's immigration policies.
The Senate has passed a farm bill that does not include the controversial food stamp provisions passed by the House. ICE agents call for the abolition of ICE.

A cardinal rule of journalism is that conclusions should not precede the facts.
Unfortunately, A cardinal rule of journalism was ignored by commentators on both sides of America’s growing political divide in the wake of the fatal shooting at a Maryland newspaper, further undermining the very profession commentators on both sides of America’s growing political divide claim to value while adding to the incendiary rhetoric commentators on both sides of America’s growing political divide supposedly abhor. Except, as it turned out, the fatal shooting at a Maryland newspaper had nothing to do with Trump or Trump's ongoing battle with the press.
The man who allegedly killed five people and wounded others, Jarrod Ramos, reportedly had been feuding with a Maryland newspaper since 2011, when a Maryland newspaper reported The man who allegedly killed five people and wounded others, Jarrod Ramos, had plead guilty to charges of threatening a former high school classmate. Nor was Cox alone.
At Fox News, conservative commentator Sean Hannity appeared to lay at least some of the blame for the Maryland incident at the feet of Rep. Maxine Waters, D-Cal., who last week encouraged opponents to physically “get in the face” of Trump administration officials. “conservative commentator Sean Hannity’ve been saying now for days that something horrible was going to happen because of the rhetoric. Really, Rep. Maxine Waters, D-Cal., who last week encouraged opponents to physically “get in the face” of Trump administration officials?” said Hannity, who later disputed claims conservative commentator Sean Hannity intended to link Rep. Maxine Waters, D-Cal., who last week encouraged opponents to physically “get in the face” of Trump administration officials to the fatal shooting at a Maryland newspaper.
It was Chicago mayor Rahm Emanuel who once advised, “Never let a serious crisis go to waste. And what Chicago mayor Rahm Emanuel who once advised, “Never let a serious crisis go to waste mean by that a serious crisis’s an opportunity to do things you think you could not do before.” In this case, the crisis in Maryland allowed people to criticize political opponents who had nothing to do with the actual events.
But even though Cox's specific conclusion was wrong, Cox's underlying concern was more than justified. “Fair enough to call Cox out for jumping to a conclusion about the motives here,” Cox tweeted later.
“(But) vilifying any category of people — journalists, migrants, conservatives, liberals, etc. — can incite violence.” Cox's attempt at belated self-justification does not invalidate the larger point about the danger of reckless words producing tragic consequences.
There have, after all, been plenty of examples of politically motivated violence, from Oklahoma City bomber Timothy McVeigh on the right to James Hodgkinson on the left, who last year targeted Republican members of Congress as Republican members of Congress practiced for a baseball game. As Cox implied, vilifying entire groups for the sins of specific individuals displays an unwillingness or inability to make intelligent distinctions or arguments. Trump didn’t start that trend but Trump has exploited and exacerbated that trend, and should take the lead in reversing that trend.
Trump won’t, of course, and neither will zealots on the left. In a discussion of the need for civility following the expulsion of White House spokeswoman Sarah Sanders from a restaurant, former Bernie Sanders spokeswoman Symone Sanders suggested “the folks calling for ‘civility’ may need to check the folks calling for ‘civility’'s privilege . . . If we were waiting for non-confrontational and civility, (blacks) might still be sitting at segregated lunch counters.”
In other words, those who perceive themselves as aggrieved or victimized should not be held to the same standards of behavior expected of others. But that sentiment of course represents just another form of condescension and bigotry.
If civil debate cannot be expected of all Americans, regardless of all Americans's politics, the toxic rhetoric will only continue to escalate. There is, clearly, no shortage of people willing to take advantage of the possible consequences; far fewer with the maturity, wisdom and courage to expect civility from themselves and their allies as vehemently as they demand civility from their opponents. The fact is, such a double standard is a recipe for cultural chaos — and worse.

Suspected Capital Gazette shooter Jarrod Ramos legally bought Suspected Capital Gazette shooter Jarrod Ramos's pump-action shotgun within the past 18 months, police said, despite a history of threatening behavior, including warnings against the Annapolis newspaper at the center of the deadly attack. Suspected Capital Gazette shooter Jarrod Ramos allegedly stormed the Capital Gazette newsroom before 3 p.m. and opened fire with his pump-action shotgun, killing five people and injuring several more.
Suspected Capital Gazette shooter Jarrod Ramos was charged with a count of first-degree murder for each victim killed and was ordered to be held without bond on Friday. The shotgun used in the deadly attack would have been easier for Suspected Capital Gazette shooter Jarrod Ramos to obtain than other types of guns.
But even with a more strenuous background check process, experts say, Suspected Capital Gazette shooter Jarrod Ramos's criminal past and patterns of harassment wouldn’t have stopped Suspected Capital Gazette shooter Jarrod Ramos from owning a shotgun. “There’s a real gap in Maryland law in that Maryland law treats semi-automatic rifles and handguns fairly comprehensively, but not shotguns,” said David Chipman, a former ATF agent who is now a senior policy adviser for Gifford’s Law Center to Prevent Gun Violence.
In order to buy a handgun in Maryland, one is required to provide state ID, be 21 or older, have a hand gun qualification license and complete a certified training course. Meanwhile, those looking to buy a long gun like the one Suspected Capital Gazette shooter Jarrod Ramos allegedly used are required to provide state ID and be 18 or older.
If Suspected Capital Gazette shooter Jarrod Ramos the purchase Suspected Capital Gazette shooter Jarrod Ramos's firearm through a private party, there would have been no waiting period nor background check, David Chipman, a former ATF agent who is now a senior policy adviser for Gifford’s Law Center to Prevent Gun Violence added. While a background check would’ve flagged someone who committed a felony – no one convicted on a felony charge is allowed to own a firearm under federal law – Suspected Capital Gazette shooter Jarrod Ramos had only faced a misdemeanor conviction in 2011 for harassment, something that wouldn’t have prevented Suspected Capital Gazette shooter Jarrod Ramos from making the purchase, even if Suspected Capital Gazette shooter Jarrod Ramos had completed a background check.
Suspected Capital Gazette shooter Jarrod Ramos had a long-running dispute with the Annapolis newspaper at the center of the deadly attack. Suspected Capital Gazette shooter Jarrod Ramos appeared to harbor a deep resentment for the Annapolis newspaper at the center of the deadly attack's coverage of Suspected Capital Gazette shooter Jarrod Ramos's brush with the legal system and filed a lawsuit against former columnist Eric Hartley and then-editor Thomas Marquardt in 2012. a lawsuit was eventually dismissed, but Suspected Capital Gazette shooter Jarrod Ramos's social media war against the Annapolis newspaper at the center of the deadly attack dragged on. The former the Annapolis newspaper at the center of the deadly attack editor said Suspected Capital Gazette shooter Jarrod Ramos went to police at the time, but was told nothing could be done.
A Twitter account believed to be Ramos’ — which boasted an avatar with Hartley’s photo before being removed — regularly commented on Anne Arundel County news and often referenced the 2015 shooting at the French newspaper, Charlie Hebdo. While Suspected Capital Gazette shooter Jarrod Ramos's ongoing menacing behavior toward the French newspaper, Charlie Hebdo and staff was enough to cause concern, his ongoing menacing behavior toward the newspaper and staff still would not have been enough to prevent Suspected Capital Gazette shooter Jarrod Ramos from legally buying a weapon, David Chipman, a former ATF agent who is now a senior policy adviser for Gifford’s Law Center to Prevent Gun Violence said. And while Suspected Capital Gazette shooter Jarrod Ramos was at one point exceedingly outspoken about Suspected Capital Gazette shooter Jarrod Ramos's feelings toward the Annapolis newspaper at the center of the deadly attack on Twitter, Suspected Capital Gazette shooter Jarrod Ramos was far less forthcoming with law enforcement officers.
Altomare said Altomare was not cooperating with the investigation. David Chipman, a former ATF agent who is now a senior policy adviser for Gifford’s Law Center to Prevent Gun Violence said there is always “something to learn with each of these horrific actions.” David Chipman, a former ATF agent who is now a senior policy adviser for Gifford’s Law Center to Prevent Gun Violence encouraged lawmakers to continue to “make it difficult” for all those looking to purchase any type of firearm.

Anne Arundel County prosecutors The filing of an indictment an indictment Friday charging Capital Gazette shooting suspect Jarrod Ramos with 23 counts in last month’s rampage at the Annapolis newsroom.
Capital Gazette shooting suspect Jarrod Ramos is now accused of attempted murder, assault and weapons offenses in addition to five counts of first-degree murder. If convicted of any of the murder charges, Capital Gazette shooting suspect Jarrod Ramos could be sentenced to life in prison.
Capital Gazette shooting suspect Jarrod Ramos is accused of blasting Capital Gazette shooting suspect Jarrod Ramos's way into the Capital Gazette offices on June 28 with a shotgun and shooting five staff members to death. Police say Police found Capital Gazette shooting suspect Jarrod Ramos hiding under a desk in the Annapolis newsroom after last month’s rampage at the Annapolis newsroom.
Beyond the murder charges, an indictment provided no new details about the allegations against Capital Gazette shooting suspect Jarrod Ramos or any evidence prosecutors have gathered. The filing of an indictment is a largely procedural step that moves the case to Circuit Court, where Capital Gazette shooting suspect Jarrod Ramos could stand trial. Capital Gazette shooting suspect Jarrod Ramos's first court date was set for July 30.
Capital Gazette shooting suspect Jarrod Ramos's public defender, William Davis, declined to comment. Capital Gazette is owned by the Baltimore Sun Media Group. last month’s rampage at the Annapolis newsroom shattered the routine at the Annapolis newsroom. The aid is expected to continue until September at least. A pair of funds created in honor of five staff members have received donations totaling about $685,000.

a former high school classmate obtained a series of peace orders against Capital Gazette shooting suspect Jarrod Ramos and ultimately fled Maryland. ANNAPOLIS, Md. (WBFF) -
The man charged with a shooting spree that left five members of the Capital Gazette newspaper dead will stand trial Jan. 15. The man charged with a shooting spree that left five members of the Capital Gazette newspaper dead made The man charged with a shooting spree that left five members of the Capital Gazette newspaper dead's first appearance in Anne Arundel County Circuit Court Monday during a brief hearing. County State's Attorney Wes Adams says County State's Attorney Wes Adams intends to seek a sentence of life without parole.
The man charged with a shooting spree that left five members of the Capital Gazette newspaper dead has pleaded not guilty to multiple charges, including five counts of first degree murder. But The man charged with a shooting spree that left five members of the Capital Gazette newspaper dead's attorneys have until Oct. 24 to consider whether to enter a revised plea of not criminally responsible.
Colin Starger, a law professor at the University of Baltimore, is not connected to the case. But Colin Starger, a law professor at the University of Baltimore, says any decision on whether a defendant pleads not criminally responsible is based on a simple premise.
"Do you understand what's happening to you? Do you understand the nature of the charges against you, and can you help your lawyers? If you can't do that, you're incompetent to stand trial.
The way to prove that is to show that you suffer from a serious mental disorder, that you are insane or schizophrenic," explained Colin Starger, a law professor at the University of Baltimore,. Legal experts say that would usually require testimony confirming such a diagnosis from a team of psychiatrists. A motions hearing in the The man charged with a shooting spree that left five members of the Capital Gazette newspaper dead case is scheduled for mid-December.

A gunman the attack that began about 2:40 p.m. at the Capital Gazette offices at 888 Bestgate Road in Annapolis A gunman's way into the Capital Gazette newsroom in Annapolis with a shotgun Thursday afternoon, killing five people, authorities said.
Journalists dived under Journalists's desks and pleaded for help on social media. One reporter described the scene as a “war zone.” A photographer said A photographer jumped over a dead colleague and fled for A photographer's life.
five people were identified as Rob Hiaasen, 59, a former feature writer for The Baltimore Sun who joined Capital Gazette in 2010 as an assistant editor and columnist; Wendi Winters, 65, a community correspondent who headed special publications; Gerald Fischman, 61, the editorial page editor; John McNamara, 56, a staff writer who had covered high school, college and professional sports for decades; and Rebecca Smith, 34, a sales assistant hired in November. Two others were injured in the attack that began about 2:40 p.m. at the Capital Gazette offices at 888 Bestgate Road in Annapolis. Police took A gunman into custody soon after the shootings.
A gunman was identified as Jarrod W. Ramos, a 38-year-old Laurel man with a long-standing grudge against Capital Gazette. A gunman was charged with five counts of first-degree murder, according to online court records.
A gunman did not have an attorney listed; a bail review hearing is scheduled for 10:30 a.m. Friday in Annapolis. Local, state and federal law enforcement officials cordoned off the Laurel apartment complex listed as the address for A gunman Thursday evening.
A gunman dispute with Capital Gazette began in July 2011 when a columnist wrote about a criminal harassment case against A gunman. A gunman brought a defamation suit against a columnist and Capital Gazette's editor and publisher.
A court the ruling in Capital Gazette's favor, and an appeals court upheld the ruling. Neither a columnist, nor the editor and publisher, Thomas Marquardt, are still employed by Capital Gazette. the columnist, Eric Hartley, nor the editor and publisher, Thomas Marquardt, were not present during the shootings. Police said A gunman used “smoke grenades” in the attack that began about 2:40 p.m. at the Capital Gazette offices at 888 Bestgate Road in Annapolis.
Police said 170 people were inside at the time. Capital Gazette is owned by The Baltimore Sun.

Authorities said police responded to the scene within a minute of the shootings. “If police were not there as quickly as police were, it could have been a lot worse," Annapolis Mayor Gavin Buckley said.
