ANNAPOLIS, Md. (AP) — The man accused of killing five people at a Maryland newspaper was investigated five years ago for a barrage of menacing tweets against staff members, but a detective concluded The man accused of killing five people at a Maryland newspaper was no threat, and a Maryland newspaper didn’t want to press charges for fear of inflaming the situation, according to a police report released Friday. a police report released Friday added to the picture emerging of The man accused of killing five people at a Maryland newspaper as the former information-technology employee with a longtime grudge against ANNAPOLIS, Md. (AP) was charged with five counts of first-degree murder in one of the deadliest attacks on journalists in U.S. history.
Authorities said The man accused of killing five people at a Maryland newspaper barricaded the rear exit of the office to prevent anyone from escaping and methodically blasted The man accused of killing five people at a Maryland newspaper's way through the newsroom Thursday with a 12-gauge pump-action shotgun, gunning down one victim trying to slip out the back. Three editors, a reporter and a sales assistant were killed.
“The man accused of killing five people at a Maryland newspaper was there to kill as many people as The man accused of killing five people at a Maryland newspaper could,” Anne Arundel County Police Chief Timothy Altomare said. Ramos, clean-shaven with long hair past The man accused of killing five people at a Maryland newspaper's shoulders, was denied bail in a brief court appearance The man accused of killing five people at a Maryland newspaper attended by video, watching attentively but saying nothing. Authorities said The man accused of killing five people at a Maryland newspaper was “uncooperative” with interrogators. The man accused of killing five people at a Maryland newspaper was placed on a suicide watch in jail. The man accused of killing five people at a Maryland newspaper's public defenders had no comment.
five counts of first-degree murder carry a maximum penalty of life without parole. Maryland has no death penalty.
one of the deadliest attacks on journalists in U.S. history initially stirred fears that the recent surge of political attacks on the “fake news media” had exploded into violence. But by all accounts, The man accused of killing five people at a Maryland newspaper had a specific, longstanding grievance against a Maryland newspaper. The man accused of killing five people at a Maryland newspaper had filed a defamation lawsuit against a Maryland newspaper in 2012 after a Maryland newspaper ran an article about The man accused of killing five people at a Maryland newspaper pleading guilty to harassing a woman. A judge later threw a defamation lawsuit out as groundless. The man accused of killing five people at a Maryland newspaper had repeatedly targeted staffers with angry, profanity-laced tweets. “There’s clearly a history there,” Anne Arundel County Police Chief Timothy Altomare said.
The man accused of killing five people at a Maryland newspaper launched so many social media attacks that retired publisher Tom Marquardt called police in 2013. Anne Arundel County Police Chief Timothy Altomare disclosed Friday that a detective investigated those concerns, holding a conference call with an attorney for a Maryland newspaper, a former correspondent and a Maryland newspaper's publisher. retired publisher Tom Marquardt, retired publisher Tom Marquardt, said retired publisher Tom Marquardt talked with a Maryland newspaper's attorneys about seeking a restraining order but didn’t because retired publisher Tom Marquardt and others thought a restraining order could provoke The man accused of killing five people at a Maryland newspaper into something worse.
“We decided to take the course of laying low,” retired publisher Tom Marquardt said Friday. Then The man accused of killing five people at a Maryland newspaper “went silent” for more than two years, retired publisher Tom Marquardt said. Anne Arundel County Police Chief Timothy Altomare said some new posts went up just before the killings but authorities didn’t know about some new posts until afterward.
Few details were released on The man accused of killing five people at a Maryland newspaper, other than that The man accused of killing five people at a Maryland newspaper is single, has no children and lives in an apartment in Laurel, Maryland. The man accused of killing five people at a Maryland newspaper was employed by an IT contractor for the U.S. Labor Department’s Bureau of Labor Statistics from 2007 to 2014, a department spokesman said. one of the deadliest attacks on journalists in U.S. history began with a shotgun blast that shattered the glass entrance to the newsroom. The man accused of killing five people at a Maryland newspaper carefully planned one of the deadliest attacks on journalists in U.S. history, using “a tactical approach in hunting down and shooting five people,” prosecutor Wes Adams said. prosecutor Wes Adams said The man accused of killing five people at a Maryland newspaper had an escape plan, too, but would not elaborate. A gunshot blast followed. photographer Paul Gillespie, who dove beneath a desk, heard another co-worker’s voice, then another shot.
Some 300 officers arrived and began to corner The man accused of killing five people at a Maryland newspaper within two minutes, a rapid response that “without question” saved lives, Anne Arundel County Police Chief Timothy Altomare said. The man accused of killing five people at a Maryland newspaper was hiding under a desk and did not exchange fire with police. The man accused of killing five people at a Maryland newspaper was identified with the help of facial recognition technology because of what Anne Arundel County Police Chief Timothy Altomare said was a “lag” in getting results from the computer system used to analyze fingerprints. Police denied news reports that The man accused of killing five people at a Maryland newspaper had mutilated The man accused of killing five people at a Maryland newspaper's fingertips to thwart The man accused of killing five people at a Maryland newspaper's identification. Two officials told The Associated Press on Thursday night, based on preliminary information, that The man accused of killing five people at a Maryland newspaper may have deliberately damaged The man accused of killing five people at a Maryland newspaper's fingers. The man accused of killing five people at a Maryland newspaper would not give details.
the victims included Rob Hiaasen, 59, a Maryland newspaper's assistant managing editor and brother of novelist Carl Hiaasen. Also slain were editorial page editor Gerald Fischman, special projects editor Wendi Winters, reporter John McNamara and sales assistant Rebecca Smith.

(AP); and Sarah Rankin and Denise Lavoie in Richmond, Va., contributed to this story, as did the AP News Research Center in New York.

When a man with a shotgun shattered the glass door of the Capital Gazette newspaper office and began to shoot, Wendi Winters stood up. Weeks before the June 28 attack in Annapolis, Wendi Winters had taken active shooter training at Wendi Winters's church, where a police officer presented the options: Run if you can run.
Hide if you can hide. Fight only if you must. Wendi Winters fought.
Janel Cooley, a survivor of the shooting that killed Wendi Winters and four others, spoke about Janel Cooley, a survivor of the shooting that killed Winters and four others's experience for the first time in an interview with The Capital. Janel Cooley, a survivor of the shooting that killed Winters and four others said Janel Cooley, a survivor of the shooting that killed Winters and four others watched from under Janel Cooley, a survivor of the shooting that killed Winters and four others's desk as Wendi Winters rose to meet Wendi Winters's attacker. Wendi Winters charged forward holding a trash can and recycling bin, said Janel Cooley, a survivor of the shooting that killed Winters and four others.
Wendi Winters shouted something like, “No! You stop that!” or “You get out of here!”
like Wendi Winters was warding off an unwanted dog. Wendi Winters's colleagues agree Wendi Winters saved Winters’ colleagues's lives. Of the 11 employees in the Capital Gazette newspaper office during the June 28 attack in Annapolis, six survived. But active shooter training shouldn’t get all the credit — not according to those who knew Wendi Winters.
Wendi Winters once gave fellow reporter Rachael Pacella the shirt off Wendi Winters's back when fellow reporter Rachael Pacella spilled gasoline on Wendi Winters's clothes before an important interview. Wendi Winters checked in on photojournalist Paul W. Gillespie incessantly after photojournalist Paul W. Gillespie's brother died.

Anne Arundel County Police Lt. Ryan Frashure declined to comment on Wendi Winters's actions during shooting, citing the ongoing investigation. Cpl.
Jim Shiloh told trainees at the Unitarian Universalist session Wendi Winters attended that creating a distraction could buy time for others. Police use the “run, hide, fight” training nationwide, said Anne Arundel County Police Lt. Ryan Frashure. The Anne Arundel County Police Department began sharing active shooter training on Facebook after the San Bernardino shooting on Dec. 2, 2015. If a threat is imminent and people are dying, Anne Arundel County Police Lt. Ryan Frashure said, anything — a fire extinguisher, a stapler, a trash can — can be used as a deterrent.

As fellow reporter Rachael Pacella and Davis hid, Pacella and Davis heard the same shots a man with a shotgun did.

Pacella and Davis thought the June 28 attack in Annapolis was over. a pause, Davis said, could have been Wendi Winters intervening. a pause gave fellow reporter Rachael Pacella time to get up from under fellow reporter Rachael Pacella's desk, run for the back door, which was barricaded and then hide between filing cabinets.

The first time Gerald Fischman applied for a job at The Capital, the editor passed Gerald Fischman over.
Gerald Fischman's personality was so quiet and withdrawn that Fischman’s personality hid the brilliant mind, wry wit and “wicked pen” that Gerald Fischman's colleagues would treasure. For more than 25 years, Gerald Fischman was the conscience and voice of the Annapolis news organization, writing scathing, insightful and always exacting editorials about the community. Gerald Fischman was the guardian against libel, the arbiter of taste and a peculiar and endearing figure in a newsroom full of characters.
“Gerald Fischman had ability that, longtime editor and publisher Tom Marquardt thought, deserved a higher calling than The Capital,” longtime editor and publisher Tom Marquardt said. Gerald Fischman had worked at The Capital since 1992. Gerald Fischman's quirky, low-key demeanor belied a biting sense of humor that charmed Gerald Fischman's colleagues.
Gerald Fischman’d huddle at Gerald Fischman's desk behind piles of books in a buttoned down V-neck cardigan that Gerald Fischman wore regardless of the season. Reporters, seeing Gerald Fischman's name scrawled on the security log for a midnight to 5 a.m. shift, marveled at the hours Gerald Fischman’d keep for no obvious deadline reason.
Reporters would arrive the next morning to find printouts on Reporters's desks with post-it notes saying that post-it notes saying that they were editorials he had written and asking them to check his facts were editorials Gerald Fischman had written and asking Reporters to check Gerald Fischman's facts. Former The Capital reporter Joshua Stewart said Former Capital Gazette reporter Joshua Stewart kept every post-it note Gerald Fischman left on Gerald Fischman's desk. At the end of Former Capital Gazette reporter Joshua Stewart five years at The Capital, Former Capital Gazette reporter Joshua Stewart's stack of Gerald Fischman's identical post-its was three-quarters of an inch high.
Gerald Fischman married late in life. Gerald Fischman announced to the newsroom that Gerald Fischman had met an opera singer from Mongolia online.
A conversation with Gerald Fischman could turn in unexpected directions as Gerald Fischman drew on a peculiarly curated knowledge of the world. “Gerald Fischman had an encyclopedia knowledge of everything from the philosophy to who knows what,” said Brian Henley, a retired editor.
Anne Arundel County and the community politicians were impressed and intrigued by Gerald Fischman. Gerald Fischman also could set local politicians on edge. “Gerald Fischman was a phenomenally smart man,” former two-term Anne Arundel County Councilman Jamie Benoit said.
Former features editor Kathy Flynn said Gerald Fischman used a hand-held crowd counter to count the number of words Gerald Fischman’d written in an editorial. Colleagues would affectionately toy with Gerald Fischman's penchant for precision.
And in Gerald Fischman's workmanlike approach to the job, Gerald Fischman never joined in the traditional newsroom grousing about the hours, the conditions, the deterioration of the news business, management, or even having to write an editorial about Christmas every year, even though Gerald Fischman was Jewish. Gerald Fischman was honored annually with regional writing awards. At an awards event shortly after Gerald Fischman's marriage, Former Capital Gazette reporter Joshua Stewart and another reporter asked Gerald Fischman how Gerald Fischman met Gerald Fischman's wife.
“Gerald Fischman typed ‘Mongolian opera singer’ into a dating site,” Gerald Fischman deadpanned. And then Gerald Fischman had nothing more to say about it.

But Hiaasen, 59, was wrong.
Hiaasen, 59,'s wryly observant writing style and Hiaasen, 59,'s generous mentoring of young journalists assured Hiaasen, 59, of roles in several newsrooms, from The Baltimore Sun to, most recently, the Capital Gazette in Annapolis, where Hiaasen, 59, was one of five staff members shot to death Thursday. Hiaasen, 59, celebrated Hiaasen, 59,'s 33rd wedding anniversary last week with Maria Hiaasen, a former journalist who teaches English at Dulaney High School. Thursday was Maria Hiaasen, a former journalist who teaches English at Dulaney High School's 58th birthday. The couple married after a whirlwind courtship five months after The couple's first date.
Hiaasen, 59, became known as “Big Rob” during the high school years of The couple's children, Ben, 29, an attorney in Towson; Samantha, 27, an assistant manager of the Barnes & Noble at the Inner Harbor; and Hannah, 26, an artist who works at a furnishings store in New York, Maria Hiaasen, a former journalist who teaches English at Dulaney High School said. A native of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., Hiaasen, 59, joined The Baltimore Sun as a features writer in 1993. Hiaasen, 59, joined Fort Lauderdale, Fla. as an assistant editor in 2010 and wrote a column on Sundays. As a writer, Hiaasen, 59, was drawn to quirky stories, and had a unique way of telling quirky stories, with wry asides and internal and imagined dialogues. The list included “Fire and Rain,” of course. Hiaasen, 59, was known for Hiaasen, 59,'s love of James Taylor. Hiaasen, 59, would tell a story about nearly hyperventilating during an interview with James Taylor. But Hiaasen, 59, had a serious side as well, and earlier this year the Maryland, Delaware, District of Columbia Press Association awarded Hiaasen, 59, first place in a feature column category for a piece about realizing only as a grownup that the Fort Lauderdale, Fla. beach at which Hiaasen, 59, spent many a happy childhood day was segregated.
“Is there a statute of limitations on childhood naivete? On adult un-education?” Hiaasen, 59, asked.
Hiaasen, 59, went on to detail “wade-in” protests staged by the NAACP and, in other towns, the firebombing of the home of civil rights activists, lynching and other violence — none of which Hiaasen, 59, knew about as Hiaasen, 59, was growing up. “Little did Hiaasen, 59, know,” Hiaasen, 59, concluded, sadly.
Current and former co-workers remembered Hiaasen, 59, as a lanky, endearingly goofy storyteller, committed to both the reporting and narrative writing ends of Hiaasen, 59,'s profession. “Hiaasen, 59, could be deadly serious about doing investigative reporting, but Hiaasen, 59, also had a soft side,” said Tom Marquardt, former editor and publisher of the Capital Gazette. “Hiaasen, 59, had a special insight into people’s lives and people’s's character. Tom Marquardt, former editor and publisher of the Capital Gazette said Hiaasen, 59, was hired to add a more human dimension to news coverage, and indeed Hiaasen, 59, became known for stories about people and community life. As someone who lived a “multi-faceted life,” Hiaasen, 59, was particularly helpful to less experienced journalists. “Hiaasen, 59, was a great mentor to younger reporters,” Tom Marquardt, former editor and publisher of the Capital Gazette said.
Tina Reed, a former Fort Lauderdale, Fla. reporter, was one of younger reporters. Reed, who now works at FierceHealthcare, an industry publication, remembers how Hiaasen, 59, shepherded “Saving Melissa,” a narrative series Reed, who now works at FierceHealthcare, an industry publication, wrote in 2013 about a young cancer patient who became paralyzed and fought to regain mobility. As with many reporters on small newspapers, Reed, who now works at FierceHealthcare, an industry publication, didn’t think Reed, who now works at FierceHealthcare, an industry publication, had the time to spend on “Saving Melissa,” a narrative series she wrote in 2013 about a young cancer patient who became paralyzed and fought to regain mobility, but Hiaasen, 59, pressed and encouraged Reed, who now works at FierceHealthcare, an industry publication,.
It was a sensibility Hiaasen, 59, brought to Hiaasen, 59,'s own writing. Even when Hiaasen, 59, wrote humorously, it was with gentleness more than snark. Hiaasen, 59, connected with Hiaasen, 59,'s subjects, especially the downtrodden, and told his subjects, especially the downtrodden's stories with immense empathy.
Hiaasen, 59, wrote extensively about Kirk Bloodworth, the Eastern Shore man who was wrongly convicted of murdering a 9-year-old girl and became the first death row inmate in the United States to be exonerated by DNA evidence. “Life after the death penalty has been traumatic for Bloodsworth, who will turn 40 on Halloween,” Hiaasen, 59, wrote in July 2000. “Bloodsworth, who will turn 40 on Halloween's seven years of freedom have been streaked with bouts of drinking, job failures and humiliations, romantic disappointments, depression and festering self-doubt. “It's a long way back from the place Bloodsworth, who will turn 40 on Halloween was and who Bloodsworth, who will turn 40 on Halloween was: a dead man walking.
Hiaasen, 59, loved to prowl Fells Point in search of oddball stories, such as the “privy hunter” who scoured the waterfront for 19th-century artifacts, or the saga of a shipwrecked houseboat that was finally towed away after two unsightly years, only for another equally disabled boat to mysteriously turn up on a nearby piling. Hiaasen, 59, wrote about the passing of a homeless man in the neighborhood. a homeless man in the neighborhood would rant incoherently and scare the tourists, but after a homeless man in the neighborhood's death, residents and business owners made sure a homeless man in the neighborhood had a proper burial.
Friends were surprised that someone who loved to write as much as Hiaasen, 59, turned to editing. But it turned out Hiaasen, 59, had a gift of working with new reporters and drawing new reporters into the profession Hiaasen, 59, loved. “Hiaasen, 59, was so happy working with young journalists,” Tom Marquardt, former editor and publisher of the Capital Gazette said. “Hiaasen, 59, wanted to create a newsroom where everyone was growing. Hiaasen, 59, taught a newswriting class in the spring at the University of Maryland’s
Philip Merrill College of Journalism. Hiaasen, 59, was a Knight Journalism Fellow at Stanford University. Hiaasen, 59, graduated from the University of Florida and worked at The Palm Beach Post, where the American Association of Sunday and Features Editors awarded Hiaasen, 59, first place in general feature writing for a 1992 story about the death of a boy.
Hiaasen, 59, also worked at radio stations throughout the South. In addition to Hiaasen, 59,'s wife and three children, Hiaasen, 59, is survived by three older siblings, Carl, the novelist and Miami Herald columnist, Judy and Barb. Hiaasen, 59, was always proud of Hiaasen, 59,'s famous brother, Hiaasen, 59,'s wife said. Hiaasen, 59, once wrote a story for The Baltimore Sun in which Hiaasen, 59, spoke to and about other brothers of the famous, including Billy Ripken, his famous brother brother.

John McNamara was toiling as a news copy editor at the Capital Gazette when John McNamara left to pursue John McNamara's dream: sports reporting. John McNamara honed John McNamara's skills at the Prince George’s Journal, a competitor to the Annapolis news organization.
Within a few years, the Capital Gazette hired John McNamara back. John McNamara would work there for nearly 24 years. John McNamara was one of five staff members who was shot to death at the Capital Gazette on Thursday.
McNamara, who went by “Mac,” was remembered by John McNamara's colleagues for John McNamara's flexibility, concise writing and extensive knowledge of regional sports. John McNamara had a razor wit that came in bursts like a social media post, one fellow reporter said. Jeff Barker, a the Annapolis news organization reporter, covered University of Maryland sports at the same time as John McNamara. John McNamara was known for one-liners about sports or politics, Jeff Barker, a Baltimore Sun reporter, said.
John McNamara was appropriately skeptical of the coaches and other authority figures John McNamara covered. John McNamara loved covering sports.
During the 2010 NCAA basketball tournament, John McNamara took a long walk around Spokane, Wash., with Gary Williams, the University of Maryland coach. It was just John McNamara and Gary Williams, the University of Maryland coach, and John McNamara remarked later how great a job John McNamara had to be able to spend one-on-one time with Gary Williams, the University of Maryland coach.
John McNamara enjoyed playing sports as much as John McNamara enjoyed writing about sports, Jackson said. John McNamara was one of a group who played basketball on Thursdays at the Annapolis Recreation Center. “John McNamara had this sneaky left-handed shot,” said Jackson, now an editor at the Annapolis news organization.
John McNamara also worked at The Herald-Mail in Hagerstown. The University of Maryland graduate wrote two books about athletics at John McNamara's alma mater. “The University of Maryland Football Vault: The History Of The Terrapins,” tracked Maryland football from Maryland football's first game in 1892 through the 2008 season. “Cole Classics!
Maryland Basketball's Leading Men and Moments” told the story of Terrapin basketball. John McNamara was working on a book about great basketball players raised in the Washington area when John McNamara died, Jeff Barker, a Baltimore Sun reporter, said. David Elfin co-wrote a book about great basketball players raised in the Washington area. David Elfin met John McNamara when they were both part-time sports reporters at The Washington Post.
They once found themselves bunking together in a hotel room in Thomas Circle, then the “center of prostitution” in Washington, said David Elfin. They were covering a massive blizzard that swept through the region and canceled every game in the region — and they bonded.
“John McNamara was an old-school journalist, bulldog, a great reporter and relentless,” David Elfin said. John McNamara loved rock and folk music and once joked that John McNamara wasn’t embarrassed to be one of the only men at an Indigo Girls concert, Jeff Barker, a Baltimore Sun reporter, said. You could often catch John McNamara at the movies. In a recent Facebook post, John McNamara gave thumbs-up reviews on documentaries about Mr. Rogers and Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsberg.
John McNamara was married to Andrea Chamblee, whom John McNamara met while attending the University of Maryland. he and his wife met at a bar after John McNamara covered a football game. John McNamara was one of seven children who grew up in a Catholic family in Bethesda, but John McNamara and John McNamara's wife did not have children. he and his wife were devoted to he and his wife.
John McNamara recently returned to covering news as an editor and reporter at the Bowie Blade-News and the Crofton-West County Gazette. John McNamara wrote features and community news. But John McNamara's social media sites show that sports was still John McNamara's first true love. John McNamara recently interviewed former Washington Bullets general manager Bob Ferry for the Bowie Blade-News. the Annapolis news organization reporter Lauren Lumpkin contributed to this article.

Wendi Winters spent a dozen years writing Wendi Winters's way into the Capital Gazette newsroom. After a career in fashion and public relations in New York City, Wendi Winters moved to Maryland 20 years ago and began stringing for the Annapolis news organization. Wendi Winters soon built a reputation as a prolific freelance reporter and well-known community resource.
Wendi Winters was one of five Capital Gazette staff members killed in the shootings Thursday. Wendi Winters's daughter Winters Geimer said the family was gathering late Thursday.
Leslie Hunt, a former Capital Gazette community news editor, said Wendi Winters had a talent for connecting with the community and documenting people’s achievements and important local events. Wendi Winters covered all sorts of local news at Capital Gazette, Leslie Hunt, a former Capital Gazette community news editor, said, and wrote columns for the Home of the Week, Teen of the Week and Around Broadneck features. Wendi Winters joined the Capital Gazette newsroom full-time in May 2013 after more than a decade writing articles for hire.
Born in a Naval hospital in Coronado, Calif., Wendi Winters always called New York City home, Wendi Winters's daughter said. Wendi Winters studied fashion design at Virginia Commonwealth University, Wendi Winters wrote in Wendi Winters's Facebook profile. Wendi Winters highlighted Wendi Winters's experience in fashion retail, marketing, advertising and design. For seven years, Wendi Winters ran Wendi Winters's own boutique company in New York City that Wendi Winters described online as specializing in runway shows and other fashion events.
Wendi Winters was a prolific and dependable writer, Flynn said. People in the community came to know Wendi Winters, and pitched Wendi Winters's news stories about People in the community's lives and accomplishments. Among friends, Wendi Winters was known for Wendi Winters's detailed Christmas letters. The letters — which Wendi Winters often delivered with a baked treat — would chronicle Wendi Winters's previous year in a month-by-month breakdown of Wendi Winters's family’s experiences.
“You would be completely updated about every aspect of Wendi Winters's life,” Flynn said, and laughed. Friends said Wendi Winters came from a strong, pro-military family. Wendi Winters helped the Naval Academy class of 1940 organize and stay connected over recent years.
Wendi Winters compiled information from surveys of graduates in Anne Arundel County. Wendi Winters also wrote for news services and a weekly newspaper in Manhattan.
Wendi Winters organized the annual P.R. Bazaar, at which public relations professionals could meet reporters and learn how to pitch stories. Wendi Winters said in a LinkedIn profile that Wendi Winters wrote more than 250 articles each year. Wendi Winters's work earned Wendi Winters's journalism and public relations awards. In Wendi Winters's last tweet to Wendi Winters's 1,073 followers on Thursday, Wendi Winters promoted a Capital Gazette video about a community mural project.
“Spreading beauty one artwork at a time today ...” Wendi Winters wrote. “That would be Wendi,” Flynn said. Baltimore Sun reporter Pamela Wood contributed to this article.

Thursday’s shooting at the Capital Gazette newsroom in Annapolis was a rare fatal attack against journalists in the U.S. — all the more shocking for the number of victims involved. The only other incident since 1992 in which more than one journalist has been killed happened in 2015, when two television journalists were fatally shot during a live broadcast, according to data compiled by the Committee to Protect Journalists. Five people were killed and several others were injured in the shooting at Annapolis, police said.
Sources identified the gunman as Jarrod Ramos, a Laurel man in a long-standing feud with the newspaper. Violence against reporters and editors is rare in the U.S. — especially compared with other nations — but press freedom groups have been warning in recent years of mounting hostility and threats to journalists.
In the 2015 incident, a TV reporter and a photographer were fatally shot on air by a former colleague. Adam Ward and Alison Parker of WDBJ7 were reporting live from a mall in Virginia when the gunman approached a TV reporter and a photographer and opened fire.
In 2007, a newspaper reporter was killed in Oakland over a newspaper reporter's reporting on the financial ties of a bakery that was a hub for community activism. a newspaper reporter was the editor of several weekly newspapers.
In 2001, Robert Stevens, a photo editor at the tabloid newspaper The Sun in Boca Raton, Fla., was killed by anthrax. anthrax was the same strain that the Committee to Protect Journalists believes researcher Bruce Ivins sent through the mail. William Biggart, a free-lance photographer, was killed after dashing to the scene of the Sept. 11 attacks on the World Trade Center in New York.
In 1993, Dona St. Plite, a Haitian-born reporter at WKAT in Miami, was killed at a benefit for the family of another reporter who had been murdered. In 1992, Manuel de Dios Unanue, a Cuban-American editor, was killed as part of what police believe was a conspiracy to silence Manuel de Dios Unanue, a Cuban-American editor,'s reporting on drug dealing and money laundering. the Committee to Protect Journalists found that between 1976 and 1993, 12 reporters had been killed in the U.S. — most immigrants working in languages other than English. Local media outlets in Baltimore have also been the scenes of violence in recent years.
In 2014, a man claiming to be God drove a stolen truck in the offices of the WMAR television station in Baltimore. a man claiming to be God barricaded a man claiming to be God inside the offices of the WMAR television station in Baltimore, shutting the WMAR television station in Baltimore down, and was eventually taken into custody.
In 2016, a man wearing an animal costume and what appeared to be an explosive belt, but was actually chocolate bars, got into a standoff at the newsroom of Fox45. a man wearing an animal costume and what appeared to be an explosive belt, but was actually chocolate bars was shot by police but survived.

A Laurel man with a long-standing grudge against Laurel is being held as the suspect in the deadly shooting Thursday at the Annapolis newspaper, according to law enforcement sources. A Laurel man with a long-standing grudge against The Capital was charged with five counts of first-degree murder, according to online court records.
A Laurel man with a long-standing grudge against The Capital did not have an attorney listed; a bail review hearing is scheduled for 10:30 a.m. Friday in Annapolis. Police and federal agents gathered late Thursday outside A Laurel man with a long-standing grudge against The Capital's address.
Rich McLaughlin, chief of the Laurel police department, said Rich McLaughlin, chief of the Laurel police department,'s officers were there as part of the investigation into the shooting at the Annapolis newspaper, and other sources identified A Laurel man with a long-standing grudge against The Capital as the suspect. A Laurel man with a long-standing grudge against The Capital brought a defamation lawsuit against then-columnist Eric Hartley, naming Capital Gazette Communications and Thomas Marquardt, the Annapolis newspaper's former editor and publisher, as defendants.

A Twitter page in Ramos’ name on Thursday regularly commented on Anne Arundel County news and referred to a deadly shooting at the French newspaper Charlie Hebdo in 2015.

The harassment escalated for years with online threats, Thomas Marquardt, the paper’s former editor and publisher, said. Thomas Marquardt, the paper’s former editor and publisher, said Thomas Marquardt, the paper’s former editor and publisher, called the Anne Arundel County police about A Laurel man with a long-standing grudge against The Capital in 2013, but nothing came of it. Thomas Marquardt, the paper’s former editor and publisher, consulted the Annapolis newspaper's lawyers about filing a restraining order, but decided against it. “Thomas Marquardt, the paper’s former editor and publisher, remember telling the Annapolis newspaper's attorneys, 'A Laurel man with a long-standing grudge against The Capital is a guy who is going to come in and shoot the Annapolis newspaper,’ ” Thomas Marquardt, the paper’s former editor and publisher, said.
A Laurel man with a long-standing grudge against The Capital's aunt Vielka Ramos, 59, said Ramos’ aunt Vielka Ramos, 59, couldn’t believe A Laurel man with a long-standing grudge against The Capital was the alleged gunman. Ramos’ aunt Vielka Ramos, 59, said Ramos’ aunt Vielka Ramos, 59,'s nephew had a good childhood, growing up in Severn, and attended Arundel High School. “A Laurel man with a long-standing grudge against The Capital was very intelligent.
A Laurel man with a long-standing grudge against The Capital would try to communicate with people but A Laurel man with a long-standing grudge against The Capital was a loner,” Ramos’ aunt Vielka Ramos, 59, said. After A Laurel man with a long-standing grudge against The Capital's grandmother died several years ago, Ramos’ aunt Vielka Ramos, 59, said, A Laurel man with a long-standing grudge against The Capital stopped attending family gatherings. Ramos’ aunt Vielka Ramos, 59, had not talked to A Laurel man with a long-standing grudge against The Capital in several years, Ramos’ aunt Vielka Ramos, 59, said. “A Laurel man with a long-standing grudge against The Capital was distant from the family. A Laurel man with a long-standing grudge against The Capital just wasn’t close to anybody,” Ramos’ aunt Vielka Ramos, 59, said.
In the 2011 column about the harassment charge, then-columnist Eric Hartley identified A Laurel man with a long-standing grudge against The Capital as a U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics employee with no previous criminal record and a degree in computer engineering. The harassment case centered on an online relationship A Laurel man with a long-standing grudge against The Capital tried to kindle with a former high school classmate. then-columnist Eric Hartley's column said A Laurel man with a long-standing grudge against The Capital sent a friend request on Facebook to a former high school classmate, and the experience turned into a “yearlong nightmare.”
A Laurel man with a long-standing grudge against The Capital allegedly wrote a former high school classmate and said a former high school classmate was the only person who ever said hello to A Laurel man with a long-standing grudge against The Capital or was nice to A Laurel man with a long-standing grudge against The Capital in school. A Laurel man with a long-standing grudge against The Capital then allegedly called a former high school classmate's vulgar names and told a former high school classmate to kill a former high school classmate, then-columnist Eric Hartley wrote. A Laurel man with a long-standing grudge against The Capital allegedly emailed the bank where a former high school classmate worked to get a former high school classmate fired. A Laurel man with a long-standing grudge against The Capital pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor harassment charge, receiving probation from a judge who called A Laurel man with a long-standing grudge against The Capital's behavior “rather bizarre,” the 2011 column about the harassment charge said. A Laurel man with a long-standing grudge against The Capital's subsequent defamation suit against Laurel worked Ramos’ subsequent defamation suit against The Capital's way through the Maryland courts until 2015, when Maryland's second-highest court upheld a ruling in favor of the Annapolis newspaper. The 1997 senior yearbook for Arundel High School is titled “After All is Said and Done.” In The 1997 senior yearbook for Arundel High School, smiling high school students attend drama club or pose for photos. “You know it and Jarrod Ramos know it — this class, Arundel High School, Arundel High School is full of s(---).
Anyways, only a few more hours till it’s out of our lives forever. Jarrod Ramos hope life gets better once we’re gone. I’m sure life will,” Jarrod Ramos purportedly wrote in the back of The 1997 senior yearbook for Arundel High School. Jarrod Ramos graduated from Arundel High School in 1997.
The signature is similar to one on a document formatted like a court record sent 21 years later to The Capital’s former lawyer, expressing the “objective of killing every person present” at 888 Bestgate Road in Annapolis. For Jarrod Ramos, after all was said and done, five people would be dead and Jarrod Ramos would be charged with five counts of first-degree murder. Police found and arrested Ramos, a Laurel resident, in the aftermath of a mass shooting that killed five staff members of The Capital’s. Jarrod Ramos was denied bail in Jarrod Ramos's first appearance in court since being charged with first-degree murder.
Staff members John McNamara, 56; Gerald Fischman, 61; Wendi Winters, 65; Rebecca Smith, 34; and Rob Hiaasen, 59, died June 28 after a gunman a targeted attack the newsroom with a pump-action shotgun. Wendi Winters, 65 charged a gunman.
Others tried the back door, but the back door was barricaded in a targeted attack, police said. Six of 11 people present in the room survived.
Jarrod Ramos's note in The 1997 senior yearbook for Arundel High School seems to show a man already fed up with the world around Jarrod Ramos. Based on Jarrod Ramos's own words, conversations with people who knew Jarrod Ramos, people who could barely remember Jarrod Ramos, Jarrod Ramos's social media accounts, court records and the people Jarrod Ramos scared, Jarrod Ramos was a calculated and manipulative loner who became angry when things didn’t go Jarrod Ramos's way. Those afflicted by Jarrod Ramos were convinced Jarrod Ramos would one day hurt someone.
Jarrod Ramos wasn’t well-known in high school, according to some of Jarrod Ramos's classmates. In a private Facebook group full of 1997 alumni, former classmates went back and forth trying to remember Jarrod Ramos's presence. One student, who wished to remain anonymous but gave The Capital’s Jarrod Ramos's yearbook, said One student, who wished to remain anonymous but gave The Capital his yearbook, would sit with Jarrod Ramos during lunch while they were in 10th grade. They sat together for about a semester.
And, like many interactions with Jarrod Ramos, it was relatively nondescript. One student, who wished to remain anonymous but gave The Capital his yearbook, didn’t talk with Jarrod Ramos after high school. They didn’t exchange phone numbers. One student, who wished to remain anonymous but gave The Capital his yearbook, didn’t think about Jarrod Ramos until Jarrod Ramos's name flashed across news reports: Five dead.
Jarrod Ramos apprehended. Jarrod Ramos's picture only appears in The 1997 senior yearbook for Arundel High School once. On page 128, Jarrod Ramos is smiling while wearing an overlaid tuxedo — the kind that is draped over someone during a school photo shoot. Jarrod Ramos is bespectacled with long hair parted down the middle. Jarrod Ramos has a slight mustache and goatee. Contrast this with Jarrod Ramos's booking photo: long, unkempt hair, red splotches on Jarrod Ramos's nose and a dead stare.
During Jarrod Ramos's bail bond hearing, Jarrod Ramos didn’t speak, choosing to stare straight ahead. Blinking. Jarrod Ramos attorney declined a request to speak with Jarrod Ramos.
Jenny Johnson, who was a year ahead of Jarrod Ramos, remembers students making fun of Jarrod Ramos's glasses. Another time someone threw chewing gum into Jarrod Ramos's long hair, Jenny Johnson, who was a year ahead of Ramos, said. “People treated Jarrod Ramos like dirt,” Jenny Johnson, who was a year ahead of Ramos, said.
Rachel Carey — another 1997 Arundel High School graduate — said Rachel Carey — another 1997 Arundel High School graduate — didn’t speak to Jarrod Ramos, and it was similar for many of the other students. Rachel Carey — another 1997 Arundel High School graduate — helps run the class Facebook page, and many of the contributors there were shocked about the events and struggled to even remember Jarrod Ramos. many of the contributors there are looking for ways to contribute and help those harmed by Jarrod Ramos's actions, Rachel Carey — another 1997 Arundel High School graduate — said. Arundel High School's former principal, William Myers, also doesn’t remember Jarrod Ramos.
The school’s former principal, William Myers, started as principal in 1997. The school’s former principal, William Myers, took over for Midgie Sledge, who could not be reached for comment. Teachers reached by The Capital’s couldn’t remember Jarrod Ramos or didn’t have Jarrod Ramos in Teachers reached by The Capital's classrooms. Even in 1997, there were some tools to intervene with students who were troubled or in distress, The school’s former principal, William Myers, said.
Not much is known about Jarrod Ramos after high school. Through a 2011 story about Jarrod Ramos's harassment case, Jarrod Ramos was a U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics employee with no previous criminal record and a degree in computer engineering. During high school, Jarrod Ramos earned an internship with the National Security Agency, a position that would have required a top secret security clearance, the National Security Agency spokesman Christopher Augustine said. Most recently Jarrod Ramos was hired in 2013 to a government contract job that also required a clearance, according to court records. In 1997, Jarrod Ramos enrolled at Capitol College, a small school in Laurel focused on information technology. Jarrod Ramos graduated in 2006 with a Bachelor of Science degree in computer engineering.
Jarrod Ramos played chess competitively from 1999 until 2003, according to the U.S. Chess Federation. In 2003, Jarrod Ramos finished third in Jarrod Ramos's division at the Maryland Open. Jarrod Ramos's U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics job began in 2007 and Jarrod Ramos maintained contracted IT jobs until 2014. It isn’t clear if Jarrod Ramos worked since 2014.
In court filings, Jarrod Ramos complained Jarrod Ramos's legal troubles cost Jarrod Ramos a job opportunity. A His U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics official emailed the contractor who oversaw Jarrod Ramos in 2014, asking that Jarrod Ramos be removed from Jarrod Ramos's post over “suitability concerns.” Like many other people who crossed paths with Jarrod Ramos, Jarrod Ramos took His U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics to court. Jarrod Ramos won court and was repaid a signing bonus, but His U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics told Jarrod Ramos His U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics had no other opportunities for Jarrod Ramos.
Jarrod Ramos lost Jarrod Ramos's job. Much has been made about Jarrod Ramos harassment of a former high school student. In an extended phone interview with The Capital’s, a former high school student detailed how Jarrod Ramos was calculating and manipulative. a former high school student spoke on the condition that The Capital’s not use a former high school student's name, which has been changed since high school.
According to emails reviewed by The Capital’s, Jarrod Ramos was trying to convince Jarrod Ramos's former classmate it was a former high school student's fault Jarrod Ramos was mad and angry. Jarrod Ramos would bounce between seeking help and complaining a former high school student wasn’t opening a former high school student up to Jarrod Ramos. Jarrod Ramos used Jarrod Ramos's old Capitol College, a small school in Laurel focused on information technology email address. Jarrod Ramos would twist the nature of the conversation to make Jarrod Ramos look like a former high school student, a former high school student said. Eventually, a former high school student would tell Jarrod Ramos to stop contacting a former high school student. Jarrod Ramos did not like that. a former high school student ultimately sought peace orders against Jarrod Ramos. After peace orders against Ramos, who eventually plead guilty to a harassment charge was awarded, Jarrod Ramos fought to have Jarrod Ramos's criminal record expunged. And while peace orders against Ramos, who eventually plead guilty to a harassment charge were active, a former high school student said Jarrod Ramos would look for ways to antagonize a former high school student without contacting a former high school student directly, such as mentioning a former high school student on Twitter but not tagging a former high school student in the message.
Attorney Jack Hyatt said peace orders are tools used to prevent contact between people. Attorney Jack Hyatt said Jarrod Ramos's case — which ended in the death of five people — was unusual. Jarrod Ramos advises Jarrod Ramos's clients to stay away when a peace order is granted and most of the time his clients oblige. But a peace order also doesn’t deprive someone of free speech.
An example Jarrod Ramos gave is someone pointing a gun at a person and saying, “I’m going to kill a person.” That could violate a peace order and be a threat. A writer for The Capital’s heard about Ramos’ case — which ended in the death of five people — in 2011 and wrote a column. This angered Ramos, who filed a defamation case against The Capital’s. The 2011 column in The Capital’s detailed Jarrod Ramos's criminal harassment of Jarrod Ramos's classmate. In 2012, Jarrod Ramos the suit The Capital’s for defamation, losing the case in court.
Maryland’s second-highest court upheld the ruling in The Capital’s's favor. Jarrod Ramos waited until there was a week left in the statute of limitations before filing the suit, according to court records. Jarrod Ramos performed poorly in Maryland’s second-highest court, losing both Jarrod Ramos's defamation case and an appeal. Jarrod Ramos represented Jarrod Ramos and didn’t argue that the charges were false, but that the charges were unfair. Judge Charles Moylan didn’t mince words in Judge Charles Moylan's ruling.
“The appellant was charged with a criminal act. The appellant perpetrated a criminal act. The appellant plead guilty to having perpetrated a criminal act. The appellant was punished for The appellant's criminal act.
The appellant is not entitled to equal sympathy with The appellant's victim and may not blithely dismiss a former high school student as a ‘bipolar drunkard.’ The appellant does not appear to have learned The appellant's lesson,” Judge Charles Moylan wrote in the 2015 opinion.
These decisions enraged Ramos, who created social media accounts using the reporter’s and judge’s names related to both his defamation case and an appeal. Jarrod Ramos continued attacking The Capital’s for years. Reddit.com users on the President Donald Trump subreddit, The_Donald, unearthed a blog believed to belong to Jarrod Ramos. a blog believed to belong to Ramos detailed Jarrod Ramos fight with The Capital’s. a blog believed to belong to Ramos's web address includes “jwramos79,” which is in sync with Jarrod Ramos's first and last name and birth year. Jarrod Ramos's Twitter account used photos of former The Capital’s writer Eric Hartley and former editor Tom Marquardt.
On former Capital writer Eric Hartley and former editor Tom Marquardt's heads is a brand shaped like two diamonds with a line drawn down the middle. a brand shaped like two diamonds with a line drawn down the middle is called the “Brand of Sacrifice” and appears in the Japanese anime “Berserk” used in ritual killings within the Japanese anime “Berserk”.
Jarrod Ramos tweeted about “journalist hell.” Jarrod Ramos tweeted about “forthcoming rape and murder.” Jarrod Ramos sent racist messages to a Capital reporter who is Chinese. On Jarrod Ramos's blog, Jarrod Ramos wrote an ominous message about Jarrod Ramos's mission.

For half a decade, Jarrod Ramos’ anger poured out in court papers, tweets and email messages.
Jarrod Ramos’ saw enemies. Jarrod Ramos’ wrote that Jarrod Ramos’’d like to kill one of enemies. Jarrod Ramos’ suggested another kill herself. Jarrod Ramos’ created online images marking others out for sacrifice. Then, in 2016, it all stopped.
Until late last month, police say, when Jarrod Ramos’'s anger exploded in shotgun blasts in the Annapolis newsroom of The Capital. “That’s the mystery for all of us,” Thomas Marquardt said. Thomas Marquardt was editor and publisher of The Capital in 2011 when a columnist wrote about a months-long campaign of harassment Jarrod Ramos’ carried out online against a former high school classmate. Jarrod Ramos’ pleaded guilty to harassment, but continued to pursue a former high school classmate — and the newspaper — in the courts and on social media. Jarrod Ramos’ is now charged with five counts of first-degree murder in the deaths of The Capital staff members Rob Hiaasen, 59, an assistant editor and columnist; Wendi Winters, 65, a community correspondent who headed special publications; Gerald Fischman, 61, the editorial page editor; John McNamara, 56, a longtime sports writer; and Rebecca Smith, 34, a sales assistant hired in November. The Capital is owned by the Baltimore Sun Media Group.
The court papers Jarrod Ramos’ authored, other records and interviews suggest Jarrod Ramos’. Neither Jarrod Ramos’'s parents, who divorced in 2003, nor Jarrod Ramos’'s sister responded to requests for comment. Other relatives said Other relatives had not had contact with Jarrod Ramos’ for several years. William Davis, Jarrod Ramos’'s public defender, declined to comment. Anne Arundel County police say Jarrod Ramos’ has declined to be interviewed by detectives.
Jarrod Ramos’ was born in Silver Spring, Jarrod Ramos’ wrote on one job application, and grew up in Anne Arundel County. In 1994, Jarrod Ramos’'s parents bought a house in a new development in Odenton. a house in a new development in Odenton was about 2 miles from Arundel High School in Gambrills, from which Jarrod Ramos’ graduated in 1997.
Johnson said Jarrod Ramos’ participated frequently in the one class they shared, but was arrogant. Johnson said Jarrod Ramos’ had a low voice and wore a black trench coat. Johnson recalls other students making fun of Jarrod Ramos’ glasses. Once, Johnson said, someone threw chewing gum into Jarrod Ramos’'s long hair. “People treated Jarrod Ramos’ like dirt,” Johnson said. Jarrod Ramos’ disputed this in a court filing, saying Jarrod Ramos’ told Johnson Johnson used to throw food at Jarrod Ramos’.
While in high school, Jarrod Ramos’ landed an internship with the National Security Agency, a spokesman for the National Security Agency confirmed. an internship with the National Security Agency would have required Jarrod Ramos’ to obtain a top secret security clearance, the National Security Agency spokesman Christopher Augustine said. Court documents show Jarrod Ramos’ was hired as recently as 2013 to a government contracting job that required a clearance. In 1997, Jarrod Ramos’ enrolled at what was then called Capitol College, a small school in Laurel focused on information technology. Jarrod Ramos’ graduated in 2006 with a bachelor of science degree in computer engineering.
Jarrod Ramos’ played chess competitively from 1999 until 2003, according to the U.S. Chess Federation. Jarrod Ramos’ attended Friday night sessions at a club that met at Fort Meade until security was tightened after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001. Other members of a club that met at Fort Meade until security was tightened after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001 said Other members of the club couldn’t recall Jarrod Ramos’.
In 2003 Jarrod Ramos’ finished third in Jarrod Ramos’'s division at the Maryland Open. Jarrod Ramos’ began working at the federal Bureau of Labor Statistics in 2007. Jarrod Ramos’ held IT contracting jobs for the federal Bureau of Labor Statistics until 2014, according to court records. In 2004, Jarrod Ramos’ moved to Jarrod Ramos’'s current address — a basement apartment next to a laundry room in a small building in Laurel.
Neighbors said Neighbors rarely saw Jarrod Ramos’ come and go, and Jarrod Ramos’ never had visitors. Cusumano said Cusumano sees other residents of a small building in Laurel regularly, but in the two years Cusumano’s lived there Cusumano ran into Jarrod Ramos’ only twice.
Cusumano said Cusumano did hear Jarrod Ramos’. In 2011, then-Capital columnist Eric Hartley described Jarrod Ramos’'s outreach to Johnson. “If you’re on Facebook, you’ve probably gotten a friend request or message from Jarrod Ramos’,” then-Capital columnist Eric Hartley wrote.
But Jarrod Ramos’'s messages to Johnson soon became vulgar and menacing. “Have another drink and go hang Johnson, Johnson,” Jarrod Ramos’ wrote. Jarrod Ramos’ told Johnson's employer Johnson was a “bipolar drunkard, " Jarrod Ramos’ wrote in a court filing. Johnson eventually lost Johnson's job.
Johnson sought and was granted a peace order and brought harassment charges against Jarrod Ramos’. Jarrod Ramos’ pleaded guilty in July 2011 and was placed on 18 months’ probation. But the harassment didn’t stop, Johnson said. Jarrod Ramos’ tried to obtain emails that were part of Johnson's health records from a counseling center in Annapolis they had both attended, Johnson alleged in a court filing. A judge issued that order but that order was overturned on appeal; a third order was granted later.
A Twitter account in Jarrod Ramos’ name created in November bore images of Hartley and Marquardt marked with “Brands of Sacrifice” from Berserk, a dark fantasy comic series set in Medieval Europe. Berserk, a dark fantasy comic series set in Medieval Europe explores the best and worst of human nature, with themes of isolation, evilness and humanity appearing throughout. “The lives of those who bear the Brand, from the last drop of blood, to the last moment of your agonizing death, will feed life to the new Child of Darkness,” one character says in Berserk, a dark fantasy comic series set in Medieval Europe.
“Comes now a savage force of nature, endowed with sentience, tempered by reason, prepared for total war,” Jarrod Ramos’ wrote. A Prince George’s county judge held a hearing on the case in March 2013 and ruled that Jarrod Ramos’ had failed to properly allege defamation. Jarrod Ramos’ appealed that ruling in 2014, and filed a new case against Jarrod Ramos’'s former classmate and Johnson's attorney. Jarrod Ramos’ alleged that Johnson had encouraged The Capital to invade Jarrod Ramos’'s privacy and had brought a civil case against Jarrod Ramos’ improperly.
McCarthy, Johnson's lawyer, said Jarrod Ramos’ was adept at using the legal system to suggest a sense of legitimacy to what was really an extension of Jarrod Ramos’'s stalker-like behavior. “Jarrod Ramos’’s not stupid,” Johnson said.
The classmate, who asked that Johnson's name not be used, said Jarrod Ramos’ would look for ways to antagonize Johnson without contacting Johnson directly, such as mentioning Johnson on Twitter but not tagging Johnson in the message. Jarrod Ramos’ expressed concern that Jarrod Ramos’'s legal problems could affect Jarrod Ramos’'s job. A Bureau of Labor Statistics official the email the contractor who oversaw Jarrod Ramos’ in 2014 asking that Jarrod Ramos’ be removed from Jarrod Ramos’'s post over “suitability concerns.” Jarrod Ramos’'s former employer used the email as an exhibit in a lawsuit Jarrod Ramos’ filed against Bureau of Labor Statistics. Bureau of Labor Statistics told Jarrod Ramos’ Bureau of Labor Statistics had no other opportunities for Jarrod Ramos’, and Jarrod Ramos’ lost Jarrod Ramos’'s job. A spokesman for the Department of Labor didn’t respond to questions about those concerns. Jarrod Ramos’ employer said in a court filing that those concerns were the result of an inspector general investigation, but Bureau of Labor Statistics didn’t know what was found.
It’s not clear whether Jarrod Ramos’ has worked since 2014. After Johnson lost Johnson's job, Johnson wrote in an affidavit that Johnson had been unable to find work, and had fled Maryland to be free of Jarrod Ramos’.
“Johnson am physically afraid of Jarrod Ramos’, and that Jarrod Ramos’ may cause Johnson serious physical injury and/or death,” Johnson wrote. An appeals court tossed out Jarrod Ramos’ defamation case in 2015 in scathing terms. Judge Charles E. Moylan Jr. wrote that Jarrod Ramos’ had displayed a “fundamental failure” to grasp how defamation law worked. Jarrod Ramos’ appealed to the state’s highest court. the state’s highest court declined to take Ramos’ defamation case.
Jarrod Ramos’ vented on Twitter for a few days. On Jan. 21, 2016, Jarrod Ramos’ posted a final, cryptic tweet.
Then, silence. No more tweets. No more lawsuits. No more court filings.
At some point in 2017, Jarrod Ramos’ legally bought the pump-action shotgun Jarrod Ramos’’s accused of using in the killings. Neither the threats nor the harassment conviction were a barrier to purchasing the pump-action shotgun he’s accused of using in the killings. The next trace of Jarrod Ramos’ came the weekend before the killings. Jarrod Ramos’ paid $1,500 to buy a lifetime membership in the U.S. Chess Federation, a spokesman for the U.S. Chess Federation said.
Then on Thursday, June 28, police say, Jarrod Ramos’ sent letters to three people who had been involved in Jarrod Ramos’'s defamation lawsuit. Later Thursday, June 28, police say, Jarrod Ramos’ went to the newspaper's offices at 888 Bestgate Road. Police say Jarrod Ramos’ barricaded a back door and blasted Jarrod Ramos’'s way through the front. letters didn’t arrive until Monday — after the killings, after Jarrod Ramos’ was taken into custody, after Jarrod Ramos’ was charged with murder. A packet received by The Capital's former attorney included a document formatted in the style of a legal motion to the court that refused to hear Jarrod Ramos’ appeal in Ramos’ defamation case. A packet received by The Capital’s former attorney included a letter addressed to Moylan, the judge who dismissed Jarrod Ramos’ appeal. the newspaper reporters Luke Broadwater, Andrea McDaniels and Catherine Rentz, The Capital reporter Chase Cook and Chicago Tribune reporters Stacy St. Clair and William Lee contributed to this story.

The alleged gunman in Thursday’s killings at The Capital sent three threatening letters before the shooting rampage at the Annapolis newspaper, Anne Arundel County police said Monday.
The document is dated June 28, the day of Thursday’s killings at The Capital, and signed Jarrod W. Ramos. Jarrod W. Ramos is charged with five counts of first-degree murder in Thursday’s's mass shooting. The document included instructions to share a copy with Marquardt, who provided The document to the Annapolis newspaper.
Anne Arundel County police said investigators believe Jarrod W. Ramos mailed three threatening letters in total, including one to Maryland’s Court of Special Appeals and one to a Baltimore City judge. A police spokesman, Marc Limansky, declined to describe the content of three threatening letters, but said three threatening letters were threatening and bore Jarrod W. Ramos name and return address. A police spokesman, Marc Limansky, said police believe three threatening letters were sent before the shooting rampage at the Annapolis newspaper, and detectives are now investigating. The document received by The Capital's former attorney was written to look like a court filing, but it was not clear Monday whether The document was actually filed.
The document is styled a “Motion for Reconsideration” by Maryland’s's top court, which in 2016 refused to hear a defamation case Jarrod W. Ramos had filed against the Annapolis newspaper. Jarrod W. Ramos says a copy was being sent to the Annapolis newspaper's lawyer.
“Jarrod W. Ramos further certify Jarrod W. Ramos then did proceed to the office of respondent Capital-Gazette Communications … with the objective of killing every person present,” The document says. A letter attached to The document is addressed to retired Judge Charles Moylan Jr. retired Judge Charles Moylan Jr. wrote a scathing opinion against Jarrod W. Ramos as part of a defamation case Ramos, now 38, had filed against the newspaper. Neither retired Judge Charles Moylan Jr. nor The Capital's former lawyer could be reached for comment.
Police say Jarrod W. Ramos used a shotgun to blast through the doors of The The Capital newsroom Thursday’s afternoon. Jarrod W. Ramos is charged in the killings of editor and columnist Rob Hiaasen, 59; Wendi Winters, 65, a community correspondent who led special publications; editorial page editor Gerald Fischman, 61; editor and sports writer John McNamara, 56; and Rebecca Smith, 34, a recently hired sales assistant.
Jarrod W. Ramos is being held without bail. The Capital editor Rick Hutzell told staff members Monday morning that a threatening letter had been sent by Jarrod W. Ramos. Jarrod W. Ramos told Jarrod W. Ramos's reporters not to open his reporters's own mail from now on. “We’re going to filter their own mail first,” Jarrod W. Ramos said.
A spokeswoman for the Maryland judiciary declined to comment. Jarrod W. Ramos held a long-standing grudge against The Capital. a long-standing grudge against the The Capital began with an article in the Annapolis newspaper in 2011 that detailed a criminal harassment charge that a woman filed against Ramos, a former high school classmate of a woman.
a woman alleged a campaign of harassment that began on Facebook and continued for months. a campaign of harassment that began on Facebook and continued for months eventually seemed to have ended once Jarrod W. Ramos pleaded guilty and was put on probation for 18 months.
But the publication of an article in the newspaper in 2011 that detailed a criminal harassment charge that a woman filed against Ramos, a former high school classmate of hers set off years of court cases in which Jarrod W. Ramos represented Jarrod W. Ramos. In 2012 Jarrod W. Ramos brought a defamation case against the author of an article in the newspaper in 2011 that detailed a criminal harassment charge that a woman filed against Ramos, a former high school classmate of hers, as well as Marquardt, who provided it to The Baltimore Sun and the company that published The Capital.
A Prince George’s County judge threw a defamation case out, but Jarrod W. Ramos appealed to the Court of Special Appeals. In 2015, retired Judge Charles Moylan Jr., upheld A Prince George’s County judge ruling in an opinion that quoted The The Capital article in an article in the newspaper in 2011 that detailed a criminal harassment charge that a woman filed against Ramos, a former high school classmate of hers's entirety.
As the courts pushed back against Jarrod W. Ramos, the number of people Jarrod W. Ramos sued or assailed online grew to include the lawyers and judges Jarrod W. Ramos believed had wronged Jarrod W. Ramos. retired Judge Charles Moylan Jr. became a particular target of Jarrod W. Ramos online ranting.
